reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated WASH and ERL response to the negative effects of the COVID 19 pandemic on the affected communities in NWS

description.narrative: Our response will focus mainly on two sectors, WASH and ERL where we seek through this integrated response to reduce the risks of the Covid 19 pandemic among the already affected people. Our strategy depends on innovative intervention to confront the economic and social impacts of Covid 19 and limit its spread and its effects on the vulnerable people, where the water, sanitation and hygiene package is designed to limit the spread of the Covid 19 and change the wrong and unhealthy hygienic practices and provide the needed personal items that will protect people and enhance their personal hygiene, while the ERL packages will work to help vulnerable people to overcome the negative economic and social results left by the spread of the Covid 19 beside the Syrian crisis through the provision of short-term labour opportunities to skilled and unskilled workers supporting 180 HHs Who will mainly responsible for producing around 155520 reusable masks through the cash for work that will be implemented. Silk Road will establish (3 ) workshops equipped with the necessary equipment to produce these masks as well as some women will participate from their homes if any (Women have a Sewing machine), while the organization will secure all other materials needed for the production of the masks. The workshops will be in Batenta, Maaret Elekhwan and Kafr Karmin and the main beneficiaries will be selected from these locations. Silk Road will seek to use existing workshops if any and in case it is not possible then we will go to establish new workshops knowing that this will not cost a lot and will not take a long time as well. The produced masks beside soap that will be secured by the organization will be packed in boxes or bags and this package will be distributed to the beneficiaries in two ways (The first by the hygiene promoters when they visit the family and the second by the head of the family who can come to the workshop to pick up the package). The sewing machines will be handed over to the number of families after the project ends ( Kind of sustainability of the project under an agreement with women, standers and criteria for selection). Silk Road will select the most vulnerable women (Families with no income generation) in each targeted community and we will prioritize IDPs, women ith disabilities, and women-headed household also we will take into our consideration the size of the family and persons he has the ability to work if any. Silk Road will study each case before producing the final list and we will transparently work with the community. Also, once we select the women, we will sign an agreement with them to ensure the rights of each party. The approach that we will follow in implementing WASH intervention to achieve the desired goals will be based on providing the needed safe drinking water to people as well as support and manage waste collection systems to maintain a safe and clean environment in addition to distributing hygiene personal supplies (Soap +Masks (4 per person) that helps reduce the spread of the Covid 19 epidemic, in addition to re-usable face masks that we will provide through early recovery activities that we will support. These activities will be accompanied by awareness-raising activities that will be provided by the hygiene promoters who will be assigned in each targeted communities(Two in each one). During this period of support (Operation of the water systems), a cost recovery system will be established to ensure continuous cash flow required for running the systems during and after the project (Only the first two months of the project will be supported 100% while the others will be partly supported), this will involve a study on a suitable tariff rate that takes into account the dwindling financial capacity of the benefiting population and will be based on focus group discussions with a representative group of the community including members of local councils of targeted communities.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency WASH/COVID-19 assistance for the most vulnerable people living in Jarablus District

description.narrative:
In recognition of the risks and urgent needs associated with outbreak of COVID-19 and increasing IDP population in NW Syria, CARE will leverage its technical leadership, operational experience, financial resources to provide coordinated assistance to conflict-affected communities, especially the newly displaced one living in Jarablus district. CARE aims to implement WASH activities to mitigate the risk of COVID-19, including increasing hygiene promotion, mass COVID-19 messaging at camps level, providing an increased amount of required clean water to facilitate handwashing practices. CARE will increase the amount of water to 35 L/person/day, reaching 15,250 beneficiaries. Additionally, CARE will work to encourage and facilitate this practice for targeted people living in camps and in communities and will distribute cleaning/disinfecting materials and soap through awareness-raising and behavior change activities.
CARE proposes to support 3,050 HHs living in Old and New Zoghara Camps located in Jarablus with WASH services in this project. The camps were built by AFAD in 2017 to host IDPs fleeing conflict areas in NW Syria. Through the funds from the first standard allocation 2020, CARE extended the new camp to host 1,200 HHs in addition to the 1,850 HHs living in the old camp and improved lifesaving conditions by replacing damaged tents with new ones, insulating tents and implementing graveling and ground site preparation in addition to securing safe access to WASH facilities in consideration of COVID-19 precaution measures.
The camps are among locations with high reported cases of COVID-19. 104 cases have been recorded in the camp. CARE in coordination with the stakeholders has completed the establishment and set up process of a quarantine zone at new Zoghra camp. The quarantine zone consists of 50 tents facilitated with NFIs. Public WASH facilities have been prepared with equipment to serve the quarantine area. CARE has ensured that the quarantine zone is isolated from the camp’s remaining sectors by selecting the appropriate location and having it separated with a surrounding fence. Local authorities hold responsibility of providing necessary medical equipment and staff.
Access to water is essential for effective handwashing, which is one of the most important measures to prevent COVID-19 infection. CARE will work on securing safe access to adequate drinking water by operating water stations, providing the camp with water (35 L/P/D), provide water storage tanks for IDPs and to reduce crowdedness around current distribution points. CARE will conduct full water quality analyses on water sources in advance. Trucked water will be chlorinated and FRC levels will be checked daily throughout the entire supply chain.
Essential emergency services such as desludging, latrines, soap provision will be provided. To reduce overcrowding, improve hygiene behaviors and increase access to handwashing facilities, CARE will install new shared family latrines where Sphere standards are not met (one toilet for every 20 people), installing door locks for safety and privacy and providing appropriate lighting. CARE will also undertake minor repairs to existing latrines including quick fixes of handwashing facilities in particular and cleaning of latrines, including disinfecting communally used surfaces to mitigate COVID-19 infection risk.
For the prevention and control of infections, CARE will apply intensive hygiene promotion sessions. CARE’s hygiene volunteers will be in charge of disinfection measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in camps. Disinfection kits including soap and PPE will be distributed along with one-off hygiene kits to all families in the camp. Volunteers will be assigned to sterilizing latrines, water distribution points and WASH equipment such as water tankers using the provided cleaning materials and disinfectant liquid.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated Rapid Response to WASH Gaps to Prevent Suppress and Interrupt Transmission of COVID-19 in Idleb City.

description.narrative:
The project addresses the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic in densely populated areas of Idleb sub-district ranked as high in severity of WASH needs. The proposed action will contain the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic and decrease morbidity and mortality through providing rapid, life-saving Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) services to vulnerable, underserved and at risk communities.
Planned activities respond directly to gaps in WASH service provision which have been jointly identified with the WASH cluster. These are made further more critical by the high risk of COVID-19 in Idleb sub-district, specifically in the dense, over-populated areas targeted in Idleb City. Informed by Big Hearts operational experience with WASH service provision in Idleb City, complementary to our ongoing interventions and designed in full coordination with other actors, the action will scale up water provision and enable improved COVID-19 prevention and response.
The project will benefit a total of 60,500 conflict affected people living in the Al Gazl station and Street 30 borehole catchment areas of Idleb City. Of these, 28,030 direct beneficiaries are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), 30,854 are female and 33,274 are children.
The action will prevent, suppress and interrupt transmission of COVID-19 through increasing and safeguarding access to safe water in areas with identified gaps. Provision of operational and maintenance support to the Street 30 borehole will begin in Dec 2020, meeting the gap in service provision since Big Hearts previous SCHF-funded support to Street 30 ended in Sept 2020. Complementing ongoing SDC-funded assistance, the project will maintain vital operational and maintenance support to the Al Gazl station from February 2021 when SDC funding will close. In coordination with SEMA, WASH services will be improved in two, existing COVID-19 quarantine centers located in the Al Gazl catchment area through connecting these to the primary water network.
In addition to ensuring access to safe water and informed by Big Hearts participation in established COVID-19 coordination structures, Risk Communication and Community Education (RCCE) activities will be delivered across targeted communities in close coordination with UNDR and Violet. This will include highly targeted distribution of hygiene and sanitation materials (soap, detergents and cloth masks) directly benefitting 17,500 people most vulnerable to the pandemic. The targeting strategy for this component with be informed by close coordination with the COVID-19 Task Force and other members to identify areas with higher C-19 case numbers and areas with dense / inadequate shelter. Vulnerability targeting will then identify households most at risk amp least able to practice positive prevention practices.
A people-centered approach lies at the heart of the intervention. Programme design reflects the needs, priorities and preferences of beneficiaries identified through monitoring and evaluation of Big Hearts WASH assistance in Idleb City since October 2019. Design of the action also addresses feedback and recommendations from Third Party Monitoring (TPM) of Big Hearts SCHF-funded WASH programming in Idleb City. Specifically, recommendations made to the WASH cluster to assess the possibility of continuing projects to close the water supply gap in Idleb City and increase the number of water tanks distributed. Recommendations regarding gender segregated hygiene promotion activities have already been implemented across Big Hearts WASH programme and will apply to this action, while beneficiary feedback on means to further enhance accountability will also be progressed.
The action is informed by recent technical assessments of targeted water systems completed by Big Heart WASH staff (included under documents) and significant operational experience with both water systems. As such, proposed activities are evidence-based, technically sound and accurately budgeted.

title.narrative: Integrated WASH, and Protection support for people with high risk for COVID19 in northwest Syria

description.narrative: The proposed action will provide an integrated multi sectoral Programme of lifesaving and life sustaining Water Sanitation and ‎Hygiene (WASH) ,and Protection assistance to acutely vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons ‎‎(IDPs) in Dana sub-district targeting 100% IDPs as 10, 758 beneficiaries (2,367 men, 2,475‎ women, 2,904‎ boys and 3,012 ‎girls) including 61 PWD in Idlib governorate, Kafr Deryan and Sarmada in Dana sub district. This is complementary ‎to an already running SCHF funded project in 15 camps in that area which will end in Nov 2020, and through this ‎project, SR will extend supporting 9 camps after Nov 2020 while the rest of 6 camps will be supported through ‎World vision . ‎This intervention will help us complete the activities that Syria Relief started in the same sites a year ago, by provide full WASH ‎service in same camps through WASH project funded by SCHF reserve allocation in Feb 2020, and thus it will make us avoid any ‎gap after SR ‘s project ended in 30 November 2020, Throughout SR WASH team, SR will benefit a total of 10,758 conflict affected people (100% IDPs) which will be as follows: Provide water through water trucking with 35 L/P/D, Collect waste and dislodge waste water- Clean bathing facilities– (SR will monitor the quality of the water through applying the Sphere and Syrian ‎standards). SR will conduct hygiene awareness sessions,‎‏ ‏with integration with Protection team through WASH and Protection ‎promoters, in addition, both CP and WASH teams will work together to provide COVID-19 awareness sessions to all mentioned ‎beneficiaries. SR will Provide Protection services to displaced women and men, including those ‎living with disabilities, most affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the conflict through targeting them with protection awareness ‎raising activities (GP, CP, RE, GBV) to 4500 beneficiaries (1500 women, 1500 men, 600 Girls and 600 Boys). In addition, SR will ‎provide case management services and individual protection assistance targeting 300 beneficiaries (75 men, 75 women, 75 boys ‎and 75 girls). ‎In collaboration with OCHA, SR will ensure the continuation of basic services, while also increasing access, both in terms of ‎quantity considering needs of PwD amp women and quality (meeting Sphere standards and cluster recommendations) of essential ‎WASH services. Increased focus will be placed on ensuring PwD have access to appropriate sanitation facilities, the Protection ‎concerns of women and girls are considered, and environmental health and hygiene promotion are enhanced. SR will stay in regular contact with the CCCM cluster to make them aware of any change or escalation in beneficiaries’ needs, and ‎will ask for their support if needed.. in case of newly displacements arrived to the targeted camps, SR will contact OCHA to ‎decrease the quantity water for each person 35 L/P/D, and also SR will contact with its HQ to cover the extra needs from its general ‎fund fund and will work with clusters and all partners , this project is part of SR plan in HPC, as the code ( HSYR20-WSH-164602-1)‎

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description.narrative:
This project will support cross-border operations from Turkey into Syria to tap into sources of information and share it for use by the humanitarian community through a team of humanitarian field officers in NSAG-controlled areas. The team will be managed by the HFOs management team based in Gaziantep, Turkey in consultation with OCHA Turkey. The project is designed to broadly support the formal coordination system, especially the clusters/ICCG, as It is based on four pillars.
1-Information gathering This pillar focuses on gathering data from the ground to produce reports about the humanitarian situation and context and inform response and advocacy. The data is shared with the OCHA coordination unit for use in various platforms and products. Info on unmet needs, including urgent cases, will be shared with clusters to address 2-Support to monitoring of SCHF funded projects. The HFOs will monitor projects funded by the SCHF. These monitoring missions will be conducted upon the request of the SCHF and based on SCHF monitoring criteria. Monitoring of SCHF projects directly improves the quality and accountability of the inter-cluster response, as projects funded by the SCHF are reviewed through the clusters. The HFAs will also receive a training on MampE tools and methods to ensure accurate and relevant information are gathered by them.
3-Community Engagement The HFOs will conduct community engagement to strengthen humanitarian response through facilitating meetings with the affected community and the humanitarian community and other stakeholders obtaining feedback from the community on their needs and the response and providing information to affected people through awareness sessions and other means on the humanitarian response and the community’s rights and role in it. Community engagement informs the overall inter-cluster response and in some cases is organized on behalf of clusters.
4-Service Mapping The existing service map app for mobile phones will get an upgrade to ensure ease of use and better accessibility such as “text-to-speech” for visually impaired people, and more visually-illustrated materials to assist people with reading/writing difficulties. The app will include a virtual information center that will 1)work as an awareness platform disseminating information on key issues such as AAP, COVID-19, and CHS 2)create an accessible repository of information for all affected persons and humanitarian actors to receive support and information to avoid duplication.
The project builds on the outcomes of a previous project completed earlier in 2021. The information-gathering component is well-established and in recent months the mechanism for sharing specific needs data with clusters was streamlined and has resulted in individual cases receiving assistance. SCHF monitoring activities carried out so far have been well-received, resulting in one of the HFOs becoming largely dedicated to this work and the processes for monitoring becoming more formalized which will be further enhanced. Direct engagement with communities facilitated by the HFOs has allowed senior leadership, including the ERC, to provide high-level advocacy from key constituencies including women and PWDs. The service map app is now available in four languages and hosts over than 2,600 distributed between medical, educational emergency, and other types of services. It is also hosting ads from humanitarian actors, and hundreds of people have registered seeking for training. The app has been well received by people in need, clusters, and other stakeholders. Building on this success, BampZ is planning to conduct a promotion campaign to promote the service map application to ensure it is used by the relevant stakeholders as much as possible. A handover plan will also be set to shift the support of the app to another donor to ensure its sustainability.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting provision of healthcare services through procurement and prepositioning of essential medicine and medical supplies to northwest Syria.

description.narrative:
The proposed project will strengthen access to lifesaving and life-sustaining essential health services within COVID-19 response through procurement of WHO pipeline of PPE supplies to support provision of integrated primary and secondary health care services to the vulnerable population of northwestern Syria. The goal of the project is to assist in procurement and preposition of the medical supplies into the warehouse inside NWS from the WHO pipeline (list of supplies is available as Annex 2) available through the Global Supply portal. According to identified needs WHO is planning to organize direct procurement of medical supplies from the Global Market focusing on specialized emergency health kits, including Inter-agency Emergency Health Basic Kits (IEHK), TESK and NCD kits from WHO Global Emergency Stock in Dubai to be distributed among health facilities in Idleb and Aleppo governates. Regarding COVID-19 response in northwestern Syria WHO will procure supplies both for the laboratories aiming to support surveillance system (laboratory Testing Kits, N95 respirators, and Gown) and health facilities providing specializes medical care to COVID-19 patients through intensive care units (ICU) for confirmed COVID-19 patients with severe symptoms and underlying chronic conditions.
To ensure that these supplies will arrive shortly into NWS, WHO is planning to purchase part of the supplies in Turkey and deliver to Syria immediately since they are under critical demand. Other supplies will be purchased from the available WHO Dubai stock of life-saving supplies and will be based on the existing needs and availability of supplies in Dubai.
Preposition of the procured medicine and medical supplies would be organized through two warehouses in Syria in Aleppo and Idleb governorates, which are operated by two contracted NGOs which will facilitate the distribution of these supplies to the organizations who are managing the health facilities to receive supplies. These are in-kind donations to the health facilities and WHO will not be having services except for logistics and warehouses. Otherwise, all active health cluster partners have been invited to the WHO supply line forum and may get donated supplies to ones who are prioritized based on the need during the months of distribution. The costs of warehousing and logistics will be covered through other WHO funds and will not be charged to this current project.
As well it is worth mentioning that considering the risk of non-renewal of the UN Security Council Resolution it is planned to deliver all goods to NWS before July 10, 2021, and ensure health service continuity,

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide life-saving winterization assistance for the most vulnerable in North West of Syria.

description.narrative:
Takaful through this project aims to meet the basic needs to the most vulnerable IDPs in Camps in Idleb and Aleppo with winterization assistance through fuel items distribution by e-vouchers, supporting them with fire mitigation activities as well provide a care and maintenance of infrastructure and facilities in addition to support schools with heaters and fuel for heating in camps. The project will target 16164 HHs 89110 beneficiaries (16,665 M, 17,380 W, 27890 B, 27175 G) in SNFI and CCCM interventions, in addition to 41788 children (19166 B, 22622 G) in education interventions in Azaz, Idleb and Harim CCCM and NFI Interventions will target the same beneficiaries as follow: NFI - A'zaz Distributing e-voucher for 2661 HHs with $150 value to redeem it with heating items for 3 months, where monthly $50 will be loaded. Firstly, Takaful will conduct meetings with local actors to ensure their participation in the project. The fuel vendors will be selected according to certain criteria. Beneficiaries will be selected among the vulnerable (male-female). Instead of physical training, as a response to Covid, an explanatory video will be prepared and shared with beneficiaries, includes how to redeem vouchers, vendors' names and addresses, WhatsApp number for complaints, in addition to banners describes the redemption process and vendors’ information. After ensuring that the beneficiaries have redeemed their vouchers, the value of the items will be paid to the vendors. We chose the voucher modality as it is easier to use and follow up, and gives the beneficiaries the choice to buy what they want from multiple vendors to avoid the risks of fuel storage CCCM - A'zaz and Dana We will establish fire response committee (males and females) in the 30 targeted camps in order to mitigate the risks of occurring fire, in addition to best response to fire when it occurs. We will provide capacity development to committees and camp management staff to response to fire through the training on using of fire response items. In addition, Takaful team will prepare an awareness video and e-brochures explaining the prevention advices to avoid fire, and how to use fire response items in case fire occurred to raise the awareness of camp residents. In coordination with camps’ management and fire response committees in targeted camps, fire points will be putted in suitable locations, where each 250 tents will be provided with fire point includes fire response items. The trained committees will transfer the training to the camps’ residents. In addition, 30 team will be established and trained (one in each camp) who will be responsible of conducting camp care and maintenance in supervision of project team and engineers. Education: 73 schools, 41788 children (boys and girls) will benefit from the provision of heating items A tender will be announced through our social media and websites. The criteria for selecting the best vendor will be identified, Selection review committee will select the best vendor and IDs will be used to complete ATC then vendor will sign the contract. Depending on the accurate need assessment at has been conducted, Schools will be provided with 1055 heaters and 77 fuel tanks. TAS will provide fuel to 73 schools that include 1644 classrooms according to the plan pre identified and agreed with the organizations (PiN, Saed, ATAA) and schools. Each classroom will be provided with 3 liters per day for four months (88 working days).
We will insist on prevention procedures for COVID-19, including distancing, procedures of sterilization staff and beneficiaries, awareness posters, crowd’s management, sterilizing DPs according to WASH amp health cluster’s recommendations in addition to allocate an employee to monitor and make sure that all COVID-19 prevention procedures were applied. The project will ensure equal access for both genders with priority for women, children headed household, PwD, sick and elderl

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Building Resilience to the Vulnerable Crisis-Affected Population in North-West Syria through provision of Education and Agricultural Support.

description.narrative:
Shafak is proposing to implement an integrated Food Security and Education intervention that aims at addressing identified critical gaps and emergency food and education essential needs in NWS through promoting equitable access and quality of services provided for a total of 56,433people 3,762 men, 3,897 women, 23,608 boys, 25,166 girls, of them 1182 people with disabilities).
1) Food Security: The proposed project aims to support the wheat crop which is considered as one of the main strategic crops in Syria. This intervention will increase resilience of people in NWS to ongoing shocks of conflict, displacement, environmental changes including drought or the medium-term economic uncertainty overall. Moreover, this action will contribute to food security of the affected populations and increase the availability of wheat flour and encourage farmers to resume or continue wheat crops cultivation. The project focuses on critical analysis of the Wheat Value Chain (WVC), supports livelihoods by increasing households' ability to meet the needs, and encourages self-reliance.
The project will be based in Idleb Governorate Ma’aret Tamsrin, Armanaz,and Benesh subdistricts. The project will achieve its aspired objective by supporting (WVC), in line with the COVID-19 prevention guidelines, through following package of activities:
2350 male and female wheat farmers (owning between 1 to 6 hectares of land each) will receive agricultural inputs and services, extension sessions, harvesting, that covers the cost of cultivating 1 hectare to contribute to decreasing the cost of production the package of support will be:
a. distribution of cash with value (100$/hectare) to support the wheat farmers the voucher will cover the cost of 200kg of seeds 70$ , and 30 $ that contribute to the cost of land preparation. b. distribution of Urea 46% fertilizer per in kind modality to the farmers who planted their wheat lands, where each farmer will receive 200kg of fertilizer as per FSL cluster recommendation c. distribution of cash with a value of 70$ for wheat harvesting that covers the costs of harvesting 1 hectare including transportation and packaging cost. d. provision of field training sessions on Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and distribution of GAP booklets to farmers.
In total, the project will target 2350 unique HHs, 13,160 individuals: M 2895, W 3158, B 3685, G 3422, including estimated263 PwDs.
2) Education: Shafak will provide safe equitable access to life-sustaining formal education services for conflict-affected school children in 58 schools in and out of camps in Al Bab, A'zaz and Jebel Saman districts in Aleppo governorate, and Harim, Idleb, Jisr-Ash-Shugur districts in Idleb governorate, by providing life-saving winterization assistance through the following components: - Provision of fuel stoves and fuel tanks as per on identified needs assessed within schools in the aforementioned locations, following a review of current needs on the ground, analysis of education funding gaps by cluster and education partners and supplemented by the latest contextual information and - Supply of fuel for heating in 58 schools (81 shifts) for the winter period of 2021-2022, to ensure a safe and conducive environment is provided where students will thrive and learn, where harsh winters in NWS can often discourage continuous access to education. The education activities will target 41,667 conflict-affected school children (19,923 boys, 21,744 girls 53.56% IDPs, of them 919 CwDs), along with 1,606 teachers and education personnel (867 men, 739 women).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the access to the basic food needs and services in North West of Syria

description.narrative: TAS through this project will work to support the access to basic food services through light rehabilitation/maintenance of 35 bakeries in Albab, Afrin, and Jendires with the integration of Cash-for-Work for rehabilitation through working in maintenance, painting and construction and other related works to these bakeries, in addition, to distribute bread bundles for the most vulnerable as 20% of the cost of the rehabilitated bakeries. The project will target Aleppo gov in Al Bab and Qubasin where the interventions will be: 1-Rehabilitation and restoration of 35 bakeries, where we will visit targeted locations and conduct meetings with the local actors and bakeries representatives to explain the project goals, take any suggestions which help in the success of the project TAS engineering team will re-visit each bakery and conduct detailed need assessment to define the required rehabilitation works which will be divided into three main categories building rehabilitation, electrical and mechanical extensions rehabilitations, and fixing or replacing the damaged equipment After preparing BoQs for the rehabilitation works, we will announce the tender through TAS channels and shared with community through all available ways, then the bids will be evaluated , the vendors will be selected according to certain criteria such experiences, reputation ,Prices, Technical offer. etc After vendors selection , contracts will be signed between TAS and bakeries’ owners/managers, TAS will contract with engineers to follow up on the venders and check their work After checking the deliverables, completing the implementation of the rehabilitation work and testing, we will hand over the rehabilitated bakeries to the owners of private bakeries if the bakeries are private and to the local committee. 2-Supporting 2134 HHs, 10670 individuals of the most vulnerable IDPs with bread for 3 months through cost recovery approach with rehabilitated bakeries owners, where after selecting the vendor/s who will conduct the rehabilitation works, a contact will be signed between TAS and bakery owner (only for private owned bakeries) in the presence of local community representatives which includes the commitment of bakery’s owner to recover 20% of the rehabilitation costs, the weight of the bundle is 800g and its price is 2 tl. -TAS will target most vulnerable IDPs who meet the criteria, which will focus especially on women, children headed household, PwD, PLW and elderly. A plan for bread distribution will be set in coordination with local communities to avoid any harm may occur , where distribution points will be adopted, as the beneficiaries will be divided to avoid crowding in distribution centers in the light of COVID-19 pandemic to avoid over-crowding 3-Supported temporary income as CFW through working in bakeries’ maintenance, painting and construction and other related works for 106 workers (males and females), where Identifying qualified workers will done in cooperation with local community and according to eligibility criteria and divided them for groups according to their experience and skills Workers will be contracted on daily basis to provide support to bakery maintenance and after updating the detailed need assessment of bakeries rehabilitation workers will be selected according to vulnerability criteria. At least 10% of the workers will be women, and they will be chosen in a way that ensures activities implementation and preserves the women dignity. Selected workers will be oriented by the engineer team and the security officer about dealing with security incidents and their payments will be delivered on monthly basis and calculated based on the number of working days for each where MEAL Team will be there when the payment is done. TAS MampE team will conduct periodic monitoring visits to bakeries to ensure that all requirements are implemented as agreed. We will coordinate with FSL cluster and other orgs to avoid any overlap

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance the production capacity of NW bakeries and supporting the Affected host communities and IDPs with Free Bread and short-term work opportunities

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention is a preliminary step to ensure more sustainability not only by delivering flour and yeast via the previous interventions and supporting bakeries to keep them in their business but also to conduct rehabilitation and support to the semi-functioning bakeries. In practical terms, families across Syria have faced heavily eroded employment opportunities, skyrocketing prices and shortages of basic goods and services, and widespread deterioration of household coping mechanisms. Food prices, in addition to other factors such as periodic shortages of staples, have led to a record 12.4 million people in Syria now estimated to be food insecure, an increase of 4.5 million in just one year.
The overall objective of the proposed project is to enhance bread production and short-term income-generating opportunities of affected households and communities in northwest Syria especially among the most vulnerable households and communities. The proposed intervention focus on i) Improve the production capacity of the existed bakeries ii) Improve the access to free bread iii) Restore income-generating assets amp increase bread production and improved economic conditions and labor market opportunities in the targeted communities.
Over 1863 households (11175 individuals: 2,163 men, 2,235 women, 3,129 boys, 3,688 girls)) are to be reached throughout the locations targeted by this project. At least 51% of the direct beneficiaries will be women and 5% of people with disabilities. Indirect beneficiaries are estimated at over one million. Participation will be open to resident families, IDPs, with the exact ratio outlined in the proposal.
The intervention logic assumes that bread bakery sector development and investment in an improved value chain, in a strategic area such as bread production, can lead to increased food security, and contribute to more resilient livelihoods while equally addressing factors that compel people to migrate by creating employment opportunities, especially for vulnerable people. It is also assumed to reduce the risk of conflicts over resources and contribute to solutions to create short-term employment opportunities and so enhance the livelihoods of vulnerable people.
The geographical scope of the project focuses on all the northwest Syria, Aleppo and Idlib governorates as well as there is a need for bakery rehabilitation. Indicatively the 19 following locations will be targeted: Daret Azza, Batbu, Abzemo, Maaret Atarib, Atareb, Azaz, Jarez, Shamarin, Talil Elsham, Tal Elkarameh, Selwa, Atma, Harim, Salqin, Kafar Takharim, and Idleb city.
Our intervention will improve the bread production capacity of 40 bakeries, 400 households under (output 1.1). 158 tons of bread for 1263 households will be distributed free of charge for 3 months duration over 16 distribution points as cost recovery and bakery owner contribution. The distribution will be under the supervision of SR field staff (Males and females) and support from the representatives from the local communities (output 1.3). Moreover, 197 cash-for-work workers will be selected to implement activities related to bakery rehabilitation, equipment amp infrastructure maintenance, and distribution of free-of-charge bread (output 1.2).
SR field team will take all preventing precautions from COVID-19 during the implementation as per the recommendation of Nutrition Cluster, UNICEF, COVID-19 Taskforce, and WHO. SR will start early procurement in order to fill the gap of bread production early in the project period, so SR can start the bread provision on time, however, all the contracting will be after signing the agreement. SR will conduct an awareness campaign on the best practices towards COVID-19, mechanisms for reporting violations (GBV and SEA).
Monitoring and Evaluation activities will be conducted throughout the project which will include: Distribution Monitoring, Verification visits, and PDM.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Reduce the impact of the negative effect of the winter season and fire incidents by providing seasonal assistance and CCCM services for the IDP's living in informal settlements in Aleppo and Idleb governorate.

description.narrative:
The project aims to provide the most urgent life-saving humanitarian assistance through integrated intervention including winterization interventions and CCCM components to the most vulnerable people to alleviate suffering in high-needs and underserved in random camps 10,532 HHs, 58,117 Ind (100 % IDPs) 11,769 Male, 13,998 Women, 16,300 boys, and16,050 girls) in 48 random camps located in Maaret Tamsrin, Atareb, Kelly, Dana, and Darkush sub-districts at Idleb and Aleppo governorates.
Under SNFI sector, the project will target 18 IDPs camps. 4283 HHs (22989 Ind, 4996 M, 5554 W, 6386 B, and 6053 G) will receive lifesaving appropriate winter assistance that is effective to prevent the negative effects of the winter season through providing 750 kg olive pomace to each HHs.
Under CCCM sector, the project will target 9964 HHs (55164 Ind, 11097 M, 13281 W, 15468 B, and 15318 G) in 46 IDPs camps. The main interventions as follow: - Establishment of 63 fire, care, and maintenance points. - Equipping the fire, care, and maintenance points with both fire and response equipment in addition to maintenance tools and equipment according to FTF recommendations. - Forming, training, and qualifying fire fighting committees. - Awareness-raising campaign for fire prevention including some of the sessions of mechanisms for reporting violations (GBV and SEA) in the camps taking into account CCCM recommendations to ensuring physical distancing and COVID-19 related measures. - Forming of maintenance committees in the targeted camps, with technical competencies in harmony with type and nature of expected maintenances, in close coordination with camp management and committees, besides providing these committees with rapid vocational training. - Conducting required care and maintenance in the targeted camps by the formed maintenance committees.
Prevention procedures for COVID-19 will be insisted before, during, and after the distribution, including distancing, procedures of sterilization staff and beneficiaries, awareness posters, crowds management, sterilizing DPs according to WASH amp health cluster’s recommendations, in addition, to allocate an employee to monitor and make sure that all COVID-19 prevention procedures were applied. ATAA will coordinate with SNFI, CCCM clusters, and other NGOs working in the same areas to avoid any duplication in targeting beneficiaries. The project will ensure equal access for both genders with priority for women, children headed households, PwDs, and the elderly. ATAA project staff will include female and male members trained on the protection principles and gender equality.
ATAA organization has developed experience in face to face distribution modality as it has been applied in several In-kind distribution projects in open areas near on inside the targeted camps, which will be adopted in this intervention, where there are separated lines for males and females, shaded areas, chairs, and drinkable water point Distribution in door-to-door modality will be used in delivering agreed-on assistance to all of the elderlies, pregnant women, female head households, and people with disabilities. in addition to all suspected or confirmed COVID-19 viral infection. Regarding the applying olive pit fuel, the findings of needs assessment showed that 66% of respondents answered that the most used material for heating last winter was olive pomace, moreover 76% of them reported It is the preferred material to be used for heating as their heaters are adopted to use olive pomace as fuel for heating.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improve the shelter conditions in informal camps by covering the basic infrastructure to prevent floods and enhance IDP access to their shelter.

description.narrative: The harsh weather conditions had exacerbated the already dire needs of the IDP population, including shelter, and non-food items (NFIs). As floods were a regular occurrence during the last winter season. Almost 123,000 IDPs across 310 IDP sites in northwest Syria were reportedly affected by recent floods. Over 22,000 tents were either destroyed or damaged. With this deterioration of the living conditions, and lack of assistance to provide adequate shelter with considering the current outbreak of COVID-19 and rising number of confirmed cases in northwest Syria, degraded sanitation conditions and overcrowding in camps and informal sites are of particular concern this and coming winter. IYD through this project aims to ensure the displaced Syrian families live in Improved shelter conditions in informal camps by covering the basic infrastructure to prevent floods and enhance IDP access to their shelter. Therefore affected locations will be supported with camp improvement and enhancing the infrastructure, to mitigate and protect IDPs' shelters from expected flooding. The main activities will provide shelter services for the IDPs as the following: 1-graveling of the camp's roads to enhancing the status of the roads inside the camps to facilitate the IDPs movement especially during the winter season, IYD will install two layers of gravel with an average of 30 cm thickness (or more as needed) and compact with mechanical machines to form a solid layer above the roads to protect them from any rainfall. 2-Drainage system: the poor drainage and persistent standing water in and around shelters can lead to numerous health and sanitation problems in camps and informal sites extending the adverse effects of flooding beyond the event itself as well the camps are not prepared to contain the rainfall volume, to reduce the probability of a flood in the camps IYD will establish a drain system in the lowlands and beside the roads, this drain system connected with manholes and closed drainage system to collect the rainwater this network resends the rainwater to the mainline, this mainline extends outside the camps to the nearest valley or sewage line. Moreover, culverts under main roads will be constructed when required. 3-Tents ground insulation (tent leveling): insulating the tent's grounds by raising the ground 20 cm up the ground by fixing bricks around the tent and fill the middle space with gravel and soft sand to be compacted manually or mechanically to make a fixed base to tents. This activity prevents moisture and medium flood during rainstorms entering the tent, also makes an insulation layer that prevents the entry of insects and rodents into the tent. 4-Installing of solar lighting poles: To improve the assess in the IDPs sites and the camp's facilities through installing solar lighting poles in the main and the sub roads in each camp, those solar poles will provide protected access to the IDPs in the targeted sites.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency WASH Response to IDPs in Idleb Camps

description.narrative:
This project supports IDPs in the camps of Dana and Maret Tamsrin sub-districts by extension and construction of water infrastructure (water network, sewage network) and connecting them to nearby borehole and water station, in addition to providing other WASH services in these camps based on their needs in ordet to provide comprehensive emergency life-saving package. In camps where it is not possible to be connected to water sources, there will be water trucking with FRC 0.2 - 0.5 so these people get lifesaving humaintarian assistance. sanitation facilities and mitigation measures against Covid-19. It aims to ensure that IDPs in the targeted camps can maintain or improve their hygiene behaviours, particularly for those who have settled in the camps as their last resort and are more vulnerable to the risks of Covid-19 pandemic. In total, 24,190 individuals (5,806 men, 6,047women, 6,533 boys, 5,804 girls) will benefit from the activities of this project.
The project consists of five main activities: 1 - Providing chlorinated water and water storage tanks (average of 35 l/p/d, FRC 0.2 - 0.5) 2 - Expanding water network, and water drainage and sewage networks in camps. 3 - Providing and installing sanitation facilities (latrines and septic tanks) in addition to regular desludging. 4 - Solid waste management and hygiene sessions in all targeted camps 5 - Hygiene promotion activities.
The interventions are designed based on the needs that were reported through WASH cluster gap list in addition to confirming the needs by assessments conducted by HIHFAD. Throughout the project, COVID-19 mitigation procedures will be observed. Gender, age and disability inclusion will be taken into consideration. The latrine blocks are gender segregated and will be equipped with ramps and handrail to make them accessible to all people including people with disability. In addition, adults diapers will be distributed to the elderly or persons with disabilities who have a difficulty to access common latrines. male and female cleaners for the latrines and maintenance workers will be selected among the IDPs in the target camps in order to ensure involvement of IDPs during implementation as they were also involved during the design of the project through the needs assessment. In Damaet Nazeh and Sanabil Alkheir , desludging will be for 3 months, during this period the sewage network will be ready and all sewage lines are connected to it ( rain drainage will be constructed in these two camps. While in Al Faraj camp, sewage network will be expanded to cover all HHs, and the already existing water network will be expanded so no water trucking will be needed in this camp. Om Jaran and Alsalihyah camps will be targeted with lifesaving activities. before the beginning of winter all septic tanks will be desludged and regularly monitored to prevent any overflow(more details in detailed needs attached excel sheet).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide sustainable and life-saving WASH assistance to the most vulnerable people in underserved areas with high WASH needs

description.narrative:
In general, 60% to 70% of the population in camps relying on water trucking and often unsafe water supply modalities to meet their water needs. In many parts of Syria, the WASH infrastructure and service provision require significant repair and operational support, with the continued transmission and outbreak of COVID-19. The proposed action will provide life-saving assistance to increase and sustain access to critical WASH supplies and services in underserved camps of Atareb, Maaret Tamsrin, Idleb, and Dana Sub Districts, These areas are considered high priority and classified as high severity of need by the WASH cluster. COVID-19 prevention measures have been incorporated across the program design. The project activities will immediately increase access to critical life-saving WASH services, while also ensuring the long-term sustainability of service provision through establishing renewable energy modalities in Maaret Tamsrin Sub District in 2 camps (Qaryet Alkuweyt, and Alqatary) and establish water unit and provide them with OampM training, and work closely with ATAA engineering team.
ATAA planning to respond to 26,799 IDPs in 19 camps (Please see the ATAA Project Locations table in attached sheet), as two-sectors: - First sector: 2 camps in Maaret Tamsrin Sub District. # of BNFS: 4291, and # of HHs: 660 Provide rehabilitation to the water station in Qaryet Alkuweyt camp, and installing a new water network and connect it with the main water tank (Capacity of 80 M3), also connecting the Alqatary network camp with the new water system, and ensuring the long-term sustainability of service provision through establish renewable energy modalities. Purchases and install water storage tanks (1 M3) to 300 HHs and connect all water tanks in the targeted camps with the water system.
During the rehabilitation process, ATAA will supply safe and adequate water via water trucking on a daily basis for a short period (First 2 months) to all IDPs in the targeted camps (Ratio 40L/Person/Day). After the completion of the rehabilitation process, ATAA will establish water units and provide them with OampM training, also provide OampM costs for 3 months (During the winter), and after the winter is over the water station can be work on a daily basis by the solar system.
- Second sector: 17 camps in Atareb, Maaret Tamsrin, Idleb, and Dana Sub Districts. # of BNFS: 22508, and # of HHs: 3893 Provision of life-saving WASH activities to the camps cannot connect to any water system and are in crucial need of adequate and clean water via water trucking on a daily basis and for 7 months (minimum 40L/Person/Day in summer season, and 30 to 35 L/Person/Day in winter season). Purchases and install communal water storage tanks (5 M3) with establishing the gender-separated water taps in 17 camps.
Mainstreaming COVID-19 response throughout all regular WASH activities is crucial to mitigate risks, therefore, the project activities will be contributing to the prevention of COVID-19 and will be a key consideration for this project. ATAA will distribute essential hygiene materials (3 rounds of soap) to all HHs project camps in line with hygiene promotion and awareness activities to increase understanding of appropriate COVID-19 prevention and response behaviors.
ATAA will help to improve clean-living environmental conditions by providing solid waste collection (capacity of 100 Liters for each 10 HHs) and conduct solid waste removal on a daily basis from all project camps. Please note Ihsan organization collecting solid waste on a daily basis in Sabroun (Batbo), so ATAA will not conduct this activity.
Please find project supporting documents in the documents tab sheet: Project Locations and BNFs breakdown. HLP. Drone photos. Solar Panel and water network designs. Water tank design 5M3, and Garbage Containers. IEC material. Risk Assessment (Dana, Atareb). Contingency plan.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Safe and sustainable provision of water and WASH service to the most underserved IPDs in Dana Maaret Tamsrin sub-districts

description.narrative: To address critical gaps, emergency needs and provision of humanitarian assistance to most vulnerable in NWS, BRD in partnership with MISK plan to respond to 7298 HHs, 41668 IDPs (7499 M, 8415 W, 12686 B, 13068 ‎G and 524 PWD) Divided over: 6 camps in the Dana sub-district (Yalniz Degilsiniz 2, Khataien Ariha, Islamuna 2, Al Nahdha, Nahn Omaa and Nahn Maeaan) and 22 camps in the Maaret Tamsrin sub-district (Basment Amal, Tagammoa Alsheikh Yousef, Abna'a Al-Ezza, Al-Karkat , Al-Wifak, Sabron, AlBalat, Farjalah, Jabal Kelly, Atta alkhair3, Atta , alkhair1. Atta alkhair2, Al ainaa, Dar Alkiram, Al Baidaa, Kawkab , Kernaz, Al rahma 2, Al rahma 1, Muzun , Alfarhan(doyouf almaara) and Al rahma 3). Project interventions are designed to achieve cluster objectives by provision of emergency WASH services in high severity needs areas to prevent and address potential drought conditions, Based on BRD experience in grant management and implementing listed activities within this proposal, partnership with MISK will contribute to BRD’s capacity on a field basis where BRD will directly supervise MISK implementation of activities in addition to its role in MampE. To meet needs for large number of affected populations within multiple geographic areas, consortium decided to ensure a better-quality response relying on consortium parties' excellent WASH knowledge, experience and full access to the whole of NWS. BRD will respond to 14 camps, 3587 HHs (21385 ind) through: Maintaining, rehabilitating and expanding water network of Islamuna 2, Al Nahdha, Nahn Maeaan and Nahn Omaa camps as well as support operation costs for two stations which supply the camps with water for 7 months. Water trucking for 10 camps. Providing all mentioned camps with garbage containers and water tanks to make up for the deficiency. Garbage deportation and desludging of septic tanks in addition to the maintenance and rehabilitation of 148 latrines. MISK will respond to 14 camps and 3711 HHs (20283 ind) through: Installing hybrid systems (solar energy, fuel) within Ataa water stations and Alfarhan, as this will reduce operating expenses and support operation costs for 8 months for the two stations which provide (Jabal Kelly, Atta alkhair3, Atta , alkhair1. Atta alkhair2, Al ainaa, Dar Alkiram, Al Baidaa, Kawkab , Kernaz, Al rahma 2, Al rahma 1, Muzun , Alfarhan(doyouf almaara) and Al rahma 3) camps with water. Garbage containers will be installed and waste disposal once every 2 days for each camp will be implemented. Maintenance and rehabilitation of 170 latrines within 14 mentioned camps. BRD and MISK will conduct HP campaigns with each team in their targeted camps, through ‎a trained mobile team (M and F) focusing on personal hygiene and COVID-19 prevention, as well as considering prevention ‎measures and social distancing. Technical guidelines for the WASH Cluster in regard to Covid 19 and hygiene promotion will be applied, in addition to coordination with health cluster. BRD and MISK will ensure proper water quantity and quality are delivered to the most vulnerable people residing in camps.‎ on average 35 Lt/d/ will be provided during the summer season (Jul, Aug, Sep) as recommended by WASH Cluster, IDPs will have access up to 40 lt/p/d. To give a better response to vulnerable groups, especially PWD and children with special needs, BRD and Misk will assign Disability and Special needs officer which will be response for adjusting and tailoring all WASH related activities to meet needs of PWD and children with special needs, which in turn will be reflected in mechanism of work and implementation of project activities in proportion to the mentioned groups, by recruiting field staff (MampF) those who will be responsible for surveying and evaluating target group, in addition to following up delivery of services, adjusting activities to suit their needs, ensuring service quality and satisfaction with access to all services provided.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improve access to WASH infrastructure for the IDPs and ensuring the delivery of life-saving services in camps in Idleb governorate.

description.narrative:
In response to the gap of access to water in 168 sites during the last two months where more than 182000 of the IDPs in northern Syria in need of water, and to solve the costly and short-term water supply and to reinforce the most urgent life-saving interventions, WATAN aims to enhance the long-term WASH infrastructure in the large camps with considering the water trucking service in those camps with the low number of families due to the high cost of water network comparing to the water trucking service. Also, WATAN will connect some IDP sites with sewer networks alongside providing essential lifesaving assistance. This improvement targets the IDPs located in Dana and Maaret Tamsrin sub-districts, which located in Northwest Syria 'nowadays experience a funding shortfall in water and sanitation services. (OCHA, Funding gap analysis April – June 2021) and (OCHA, Report No. 25, 2021). To this aim, the planned intervention will respond to the needs of 16101 individuals IDPs (3285 men, 4065 women, 4236 boys, and 4515 girls) through the following strategies:
Water infrastructure for 6 IDP sites to ensure 35-40 lt/p/d during the months of July, August, September, and October, and 30-35 lt/p/d for the rest of the year of safe water for drinking and personal hygiene, which will be supported by the solar system to reduce the operational cost to almost zero.
Introducing solar systems in total 5 IDP sites as an energy source of water stations.
With a sustainable and innovative solar system to ensure IDPs' needs, WATAN is aware of the scope of the solar system during winter. As a response, during the rehabilitation period, water trucking service will be available for 3 months, and supporting the operation and maintenance of water systems during winter months will be applied in the water stations to ensure the functionality of the water systems and avoid any low-efficiency systems because of the weather.
Water trucking in 11 camps, 5 camps will be covered for 3 months alongside the rehabilitation of water systems, and 6 camps will be covered for 7 months.
Water quality monitoring will be applied to ensure that the FRC at the range of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/l.
Construction of 2 high reservoirs (100 m3) and 1 ground reservoir (80 m3) to ensure the availably of water storage capacity in the 3 of the largest IDP sites while the other sites have water tanks as a storage capacity.
Rehabilitation and installation of the sewer networks in 5 IDP sites to ensure safe access to sanitation infrastructure. During the rehabilitation works, emergency sanitation services through desludging will be provided for three months.
The intervention will cover solid waste management activities on daily basis in 11 IDP sites which include the operation of waste removal trucks, and waste removal workers. The collected waste will be dumped into formal dumping sites in Dana and Maaret Tamsrin sub-districts.
RCCE intervention that aligned with COVID-19 outbreak will be applied through sharing the awareness information among the camps' residents. This activity will be a complementary activity from WATAN.
Shelter in camps activities in 12 camps with tent installation and tent replacement, tents graveling, and NFI CRI items kits distribution will be complementary services from WATAN.
One of the key successes of this intervention that the solar system that will be installed in the “Alfarhan” water station and will feed Al-Karkat and Has camps, this water station will also support another 7 camps hosting 10,872 IDPs (Indirect Beneficiaries). These camps are Al-Rahma 1, Al-Rahma 2, Al-Rahma 3, Alfarhan(Doyouf Almaara), Atta alkhair, Muzun, Kelly( Al Rayhan) located in the same area.
This intervention will address the HRP Strategic Objective 1, and it is directly linked with the 2021 Third Reserve Allocation Strategic Objective and 2021 First Allocation Strategic Objective 1.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of quality and inclusive learning opportunities for girls and boys affected by the humanitarian crisis in Northwest Syria (SO2)

description.narrative:
This project supports children in Idleb and Aleppo from the host community and IDPs, which includes the most vulnerable groups (children under 12 years, IDP children, children with difficulties (incl. disabilities and disorders later only referred to as children with difficulties) to provide equitable access for quality learning opportunities for girls and boys in both primary and secondary school level in both formal and non-formal settings. The implementation approach will be focusing on the adoption of the education program in Violet to ensure the continuity of education and provide access to learning opportunities throughout three modalities (physical, blended, distance) due to the COVID-19 pandemic by delivering quality education in the existing formal and non-formal learning spaces in the targeted locations that Violet has supported through SCHF fund. The project design complies with INEE minimum standards and safe-programming principles for children to ensure that children have access to inclusive and equitable quality education that provides lifelong learning opportunities.
Violet aims to achieve the overall change by improving student resilience and learning outcomes – specifically, improved resilience for up to 12,772 children (at least 6,396) girls and 307 children with difficulties achieving improved basic learning outcomes through: - The provision of education through three modalities to ensure the continuity of education and all groups of children have access to quality education in all context settings with prompting safeguarding in learning facilities. - The provision of incentives has a positive impact on teacher (51% females) attendance and retention - Return to the normal physical education when relevant, provision of formal education with complementary remedial and catch-up classes which ends by re-entering the students into formal education after a short-term intervention - The Ongoing teacher professional development and support effectively equip teachers with the skills to provide protective and quality education in the supported learning spaces online during distance learning and in-person in physical and blended learning. - Enhanced participation by children, parents/caregivers, and communities in supporting children’s education and protection - Provide support for children with more significant functioning problems, ensure to implement the RECU design in the education facilities (Reach, Enter, Circulate, Use) to fully mainstream disability in education - Implement comprehensive health and hygiene protocols and awareness-raising on COVID-19 particularly - Conduct safeguarding activities and scale up a suite of activities designed to help keep children safe, including emergency preparedness and response activities.
Over the past 8 years, Violet has been working towards building the education system in Northwest Syria by formal and non-formal education in and out of camps with key activities in this project Violet’s education team is skilled and equipped to successfully implement the project's scope of work. To continuously enhance the quality of programs delivered in Northwest Syria, Violet is eager to engage in research and learning. On a project level, Violet is regularly conducting lessons learned based on the organization’s learning policies. Violet contributed to Manahel’s digital platform for distance learning. Violet maintains good relations with the directorates in Idleb and Aleppo, and with community representatives and other stakeholders. Coordination takes place for high-level topics such as MoUs with the EDs for medium-level coordination, Violet will coordinate with education clusters to getting their support in facilitating the implementation of the activities. Violet showed flexibility and adaptability to context changes to uphold access and quality such as home-based and distance learning.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance Safe Access to Formal Education Services for School-Aged-Children in The Underserved and High-Needs Areas of Atareb, Dana, Darkosh, and Qourqeena Sub-districts

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention's overall objective is to improve equitable access for school-aged children to safe, inclusive, and quality learning environments to foster their resilience. This will be achieved through implementing a package of education activities to 19 formal schools in Atareb, Dana, Darkosh, and Qourqeena sub-districts which are located in underserved and high-needs areas, where11,766 children (5,581 boys and 6,185 girls 'including 302 CwD ~2.5%', 5-17 years old) are enrolled (65% IDPs). The project builds on previous projects' successes, funded by Save the Children, UNICEF, and SCHF. The proposed schools need funding for the time being. So, there will be a big chance for 11,766 school-aged children to lose their education opportunities in addition to 480 education personnel who will lose their only source of income in case these schools aren’t supported. By supporting a quality learning environment, IRD seeks to increase children's enrollment in the targeted schools. To achieve this, IRD will conduct digital Back To Learning (BTL) campaigns 'to minimize gathering and as a precautionary measure for COVID-19' in 14 communities for raising awareness among parents and community members regarding the importance of education. All enrolled students will receive formal education services using the SiG curriculum for 9 months (Sep 21 to May 22). 20% of these students will conduct ASER tests twice. The baseline will be conducted during October 2021 and the end line will be conducted during April 2022 to measure the learning outcomes of the project on students. To improve the students’ well-being during the project lifetime, all enrolled students will receive recreational activities from their classroom teachers. All teachers will be provided with monthly incentives to increase their motivation and ensure their retention in schools. The project will cover the schools’ monthly operational costs, including recreational materials, refreshment, cleaning, hygiene materials, and stationery, conducting light repairs for schools, provision of students' and teachers' kits. The quality of education will be improved through contextualized and targeted teacher training and further support to their professional development within each school by delivering (CSG, TiCC, PSEA, COVID-19) trainings. IRD will cover the costs of these trainings from another funding. Parents Teachers Associations (PTAs) will be a component in the activities of this project. Quarterly meetings for PTAs members will be held to discuss what was achieved in the last period and set with IRD’s staff plans for the upcoming period. Due to COVID-19, there will be comprehensive precautionary measures in the 19 schools, including periodic sterilization process for classrooms and WASH facilities, awareness sessions for students, training for teachers and educational staff, and sterilization provision materials for all schools. IRD will re-utilize all the preexisted IT equipment (laptops and printers) from its previous various education projects.
Plan B: All schools are now operational. In case of COVID-19 out-break again, schools may be suspended and close temporarily. As a plan B, the project will adapt the distance learning modality tested during 2020 through 4 education projects implemented by IRD and provide children with internet vouchers (which will be covered from running costs). WhatsApp groups will be created per subject and per class. Teachers will prepare their lessons and record the lessons to be shared with students. In case there will be a part-time suspension, the blended education approach will be applied. It is a mix of physical attendance and distance learning methods.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting Economic Recovery and Community Resilience in North West Syria

description.narrative:
The project is based on supporting 752 male and female from IDPs and HHS and enhancing their economic capacity by securing income-generating opportunities for them, by providing grants to support projects for 440 male and female with previous experiences or whose projects have been damaged by Covid 19 in addition to providing grants to support projects for 60 people with disabilities (PWD) that suits their disability and re-integrates them into their society, and also by providing vocational training for a 216 male and female and 36 of PWD, followed by a paid employment and internship in the labor market for three months. taking into account their reintegration into society. the project will be in the three locations of Azaz, Dana and Maarat Misrin The project has four intervention : 1st: support projects for 440 (M, F) who have previous experience or have projects affected by COVID-19, where Takaful (TAS) will form 3 Community Representation Committees (CRC) which will receive training to study, evaluate and development of Small-Micro business. The beneficiaries' selection will be in two phases, 220 beneficiaries in each phase, after that monitoring of the local market will be conducted regularly to ensure that no harm was caused, a one-day session will be conducted to explain the mechanism of applying then CRC and Takaful team will evaluate the submitted projects and select best projects, Takaful will provide the final selected beneficiaries with training about ( product study-marketing- accounting,,). The grant will be $1000 and will be cash linked to (assets, tools). Takaful will work to provide the grant in the form of two payments to ensure that the beneficiary is serious.
2nd: Providing Small-Micro Businesses to support 60 PWD (MampF) who have the experience to set up a small income-generating project which fit with their special situation. We will select the beneficiaries and interview them after that The Washington scale will be used, which determines, the percentage of disability, TAS will purchase the needed materials and deliver it in-kind because of their physical difficulties of PWD. The grant amount will be valued at $1,000. The project team will conduct periodical visits to business places to ensure that the businesses are on the path and provide required recommendations. At the end of the two interventions Takaful will provide financial awards with 200 USD to the top 50 projects based on progress, income generated.
3rd: Providing vocational training (VT) for 216 males and females for three months and then provide internships to them in the market for the other three months supported by the project. TAS will update the market needs and needed professions. The appropriate professions and training will according to two groups: 1 the professions which do not require any qualifications. e.g.: Hairdressing, and Sewing. 2 the professions which require relevant experience e.g. Computer Maintenance, Web Development. Three months paid internship will be provided by contracting with the business owners and TAS will provide allowances to the beneficiaries for three months, $88 per month, that will make the beneficiary gain the confidence of the employer and gain practical experience.
4th: Vocational Training for PwDs for 3 months followed by other 3-months paid internship. TAS will secure the necessary transportation back and forth for beneficiaries with disabilities. The PWD beneficiaries will be employed in the market for three months, and the project will provide their allowances with $88 per month.
In the end, a fair job will be held in each of the targeted locations for all beneficiaries to display their products and works to gain the confidence of the local community in their experiences. Related to the Covid-19 pandemic, TAS ensuring all precautionary measures through disinfecting meeting venues before and distributing masks to attendees, printing guiding instructions

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing socio-economic resilience of communities affected by protracted civil war, the COVID-19 pandemic, floods, and economic deterioration through diverse livelihood opportunities for the most vulnerable groups in Dana sub-district

description.narrative: This project delivers a strategic and integrated set of interventions to restore local economy in Dana, Idleb in the aftermath of protracted conflict further aggravated by the impact of the COVID19 pandemic, and deteriorated economic situation. Its main objective is to create income generating opportunities for the most vulnerable IDPs, and host community members in the targeted locations. The project proposes an integrated protection and livelihood intervention where the most vulnerable households (HHs) (those being referred from child protection case management actors and GBV case management actors, as well as PwDs) will be directly targeted to enhance their resilience and promote their access to employment and entrepreneurship opportunities. The project formulation has been based in needs as identified in multi-cluster RNA/REACH/HNAP data. Besides, firsthand consultations, conducted specifically for this project with local stakeholders, have also informed the design of this proposal. By pursuing the referred main objective, the project aims to achieve the following outcomes: 1. Essential socioeconomic services are revived and restored through the creation of short-term work opportunities 2. Access to inclusive livelihoods and entrepreneurship support is enhanced through vocational training (VT) 3. Local small businesses and entrepreneurs are supported 4. Social cohesion among IDPs and host communities is enhanced For this purpose, a set of interlinked activities will be conducted in coordination with FSL, WASH, Shelter and Protection clusters. Firstly, 10 essential socioeconomic infrastructures will be rehabilitated in Dana, through the creation of 240 short-term work opportunities for the most vulnerable HHs, in coordination with the FSL partners to ensure that the intervention is synergistic with food assistance. Secondly, the project foresees the identification of 450 HHs with a specific focus on severe economic vulnerability to provide them with VT linked to either CfW opportunities or small business support. These opportunities will be directly aiming to address Protection concerns, targeting PwDs, GBV survivors and HHs where cases of child labor have been identified.Thirdly, the project will identify and provide business support to 120 small businesses affected by floods, economic recession and COVID19 in the targeted location, to boost economic recovery. Moreover, the project is specifically designed to foster social cohesion among IDPs and host communities through the establishment of a Socio-Economic Empowerment Community Committee (SEECC) for advising the design and implementation of the project activities, fostering local ownership and ensuring sustainability of the achievements of the project upon its completion. This project will directly benefit 373,320 individuals living in 9 communities and 18 camps in Dana (M:132980, F:94450, B:64410, G:81480, PWD: 5690). UNDP is the global lead agency in Early Recovery and Livelihoods Restoration with extensive experience in ERL projects, including inside NWS.UNDP will work in partnership with SARD, a national NGO which has experience in both ERL and Protection projects. UNDP will be responsible for overall management of the project and oversight against programmatic and fiduciary risks through efficient contractual arrangements and administrative support. This will ensure timely implementation of the project, and high quality of activities and program deliverables. Moreover, UNDP’s ERL team will provide technical guidance and expertise to ensure the quality and appropriateness of livelihood activities, the sustainability of the business support which will improve the effectiveness of the project and better outcomes for BNs. The added value of SARD is anchored around their experience in both ERL and Protection activities in Idleb, which will be a key to ensure the smooth transitioning between protection activities to livelihood activities for the most vulnerable

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Continue the provision of life-saving integrated activities including the basic and secondary formal and non-formal Education, Protection services and WASH-in-schools to the most vulnerable individuals in Northern parts of Syria

description.narrative: The project will support 22 schools in Maaret Tamsrin, Teftnaz, and Dana Sub-districts having high severity scale (21 in camps and 1 in a village) that are funded by HF amp ATAA but will have no funds after May 2021 (attached signed confirmation letters). The project will have integrated services under Education, CP and WASH. Education: The direct beneficiaries will be children in BE amp secondary (1st till 12th grades) including CWDs who will be provided with FE amp NFE, 10427 children (boys 5245, Girls 4910, CWD boys 169, CWD Girls 103) and 463 staff (M:286, F:177). The project will focus mainly on enhancing the infrastructure based on a comprehensive rehabilitation assessment (attached rehabilitation needs) by providing minor rehabilitation to all schools to achieve safe, equitable and protective education considering COVID-19 measures.
