Also, this project will involve empowering mothers and HH members through training to screen their own children for malnutrition by teaching them how to use color-coded Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) tapes and check for Odema.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing lifesaving preventive and curative nutrition services for vulnerable population groups with attention to children and women with special needs in NW Syria.

description.narrative:
In response to the demonstrated nutrition needs on the ground, Human Appeal Turkey (HAT) and Social Development International (SDI) proposes to jointly operate 11 nutrition rapid response teams (RRTs) across North West Syria (NWS) targeting the children under 5 (CU5) and pregnant and lactating women (PLWs) among others of the most vulnerable groups within the areas of priority (As per the nutrition cluster and this allocation paper) with essential life-saving curative and preventative nutrition services as follows:
- HAT: Establishment and operation of 4 RRTs in Dana sub-district for a duration of 11 months (Locations are coordinated with the nutrition cluster).
- SDI: Operation of pre-existing 7 RRTs: 2 in Afrin, 1 in Maaret Tamisrin, 3 in dana, and 1 in Salqin sub-districts for a duration of 12 months.
The project will be implemented in 23 communities across 4 sub- districts (Dana, Maaret Tamisrin, Afrin and Salqin) provide nutrition services for 83546 beneficiaries including (19200 Pregnant and lactating women 44800 children under five years and 19546 other caregivers (men and women)) (79918 IDPs and 3628 HCs) (1800 PWDs).
HAT and SDI will collaborate to promote the ultimate utilization of the pre-existing resources and expertise relevant to the intervention including the use of the trained staff at both organizations and the shared usage of the assembly points, warehouses, OTPs as well as the exchange of relevant technical expertise and measures of access and coordination at the field level. It’s imperative to mention that both HAT and SDI will make sure that the above will not result in increased costing of the proposed intervention. On the contrary, having such complementarity measures in place will potentially lead to overall cost effectiveness of the project.
The proposed RRTs are planned to function according to the TORs and SOPs adopted by the nutrition cluster, and they will be providing the following nutrition services:
Screening 44800 children 6-59 months, and 19200 PLWs, referral and follow up who are malnourished. Provide emergency IYCF counseling for 7750 caregivers including PLWs. Disseminating messages on IYCF-E recommended feeding practices, for 30.000 caregivers including PLWs.
Screen, referral CU5 and PLWs with dangers signs and Medical problems. Support hygiene promotion and rising WASH awareness by providing Key messages to prevent the risk of COVID 19 transmission and other infections. Identify visual signs of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs during Nutrition screening. Capacity building of 60 frontline nutrition services providers on IYCF-E and CMAM programs in the context of COVID-19 and provide continuous technical support for human appeal teams to build their capacity and strengthen their experience in nutrition field work.
As a part to COVID 19 response, the partners are going to apply adjustments of the nutrition activities to mitigate the risk of infection while ensuring continuity of life-saving nutrition services, where they are going to integrate key messages on hygiene and COVID-19 symptoms, and (IPC) measures, implement a simplified protocol for the treatment of acute malnutrition, use a separate MUAC tape for each child and PLW, distribute micronutrients for two months in advance if available, screen and refer suspected COVID-19 cases, applying recommended IPC measures, provide IYCF-E counseling, either at the appropriate distance of 1 meters apart or remotely by phone or video and disseminate IYCF-E messages use platforms such as text messages and WhatsApp videos, posters in public places. The partners will train the caregivers of MAM and SAM cases on MUAC and edema screening, referral, recognize signs of deterioration, and give them a mobile or WhatsApp number of the CHW to contact in case the child’s condition deteriorates.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing Integrated Emergency Nutrition Services for People in Need in NW Syria

description.narrative: Through this project, UOSSM aims to provide life-saving integrated nutrition services by supporting 10 Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) in Al Dana (with 189,523 HCs and 844,187 IDPs) and Maaret Tamsrin (with 73,256 HCs and 220,525 IDPs) sub-districts, targeting PIN Children under five (CU5) and caregivers including pregnant and lactating women (PLWs) and people with disabilities. These areas have 74 camps according to CCCM with 76,033 IDPs. The proposed activities will be for 12 months including 1-month preparation. The RRTs are distributed between the targeted communities according to the number of IDPs as follows: 3 RRTs in Deir Hasan, 3 RRTs in Atma, 3 RRTs in Aqrabat, and 1 RRT in Bahouri, Alshiek Baher, and Maaret Tamsrin. These RRTs will be linked to UOSSM’s health facilities in the targeted communities which will receive the referred cases by RRTs. Each RRT is expected to reach 30 beneficiaries (22 CU5 and 8 PLWs) per day, so it is expected to deliver integrated nutrition services to a total of 82,500 (60,500 CU5 and 22,000 PLWs) equal (76,033 IDPs and 6,467 HCs) new beneficiaries and following up beneficiaries. The RRTs will visits each beneficiary multiple times based on the need within the project period. RRTs’ main activities will include: Strengthening early case finding, treatment for MAM and SAM cases without complications in case supplies is available from UNICEF. If the supplies are unavailable, SAM and MAM cases will be referred to UOSSM’s health facility in the same community. Providing screening, treatment, and follow-up, and referring the complicated malnutrition cases to the nearest hospitals (Sarmada - Al-Sham Humanitarian, Atma - Hand in Hand for Aid and Development, Maaret Tamsrin - Shafak) to ensure the completion of CMAM program cycle. Referring beneficiaries with dangerous signs to the health facilities for treatment. Providing emergency IYCF counseling for mothers with moderately malnourished children, and micronutrient distribution for preventing anemia and malnutrition among children and PLWs. RRTs will support integrated nutrition services with hygiene promotion. Screening and referring CU5 and PLWs with signs of abuse/violence to GBV case management and women and girls’ safe space (WGSS) centers to receive services according to their needs. According to UNICEF and Nutrition cluster protocols, to enable RRTs to deliver integrated nutrition services with high quality, UOSSM aims to conduct IYCF amp CMAM training during the first quarter. UOSSM also will support the training platform and deliver COVID-19 online training course to RRT’s staff in the field of the COVID-19 pandemic, besides, conduct GBV training for all members of RRTs staff. On the other hand, UOSSM’s MampE team developed the monitoring plan where the MampE team monitors implementation of project activities in the field through field visits, conducting beneficiaries satisfaction, controlling services quality, following up the progress of activities, and achieve indicators monthly and quarterly. Nutrition programmatic adjustments will be implemented in the context of COVID-19 to mitigate the risk of infection while ensuring continuity of life-saving nutrition services. Furthermore, RRTs teams will be provided with PPE during delivering services.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support the continuation of lifesaving preventive and curative nutrition services in northwest Syria by RRTs

description.narrative: QRCS aims through the proposed project to ensure continuity and increase the coverage of life-saving preventive and curative nutrition services among children under 5 (boys and girls) and PLWs. QRCS has been supporting seven fixed OTPs centers and 6 mobile rapid response teams reported on monthly 4Ws in coordination with nutrition clusters, UN agencies, health directorates, and local stakeholders in which targeted areas are ranked as a high severity according to the HNO 2021 and nutrition cluster reports, at 29 communities including IDPs camps and host communities in Idleb and rural Aleppo. QRCS will continue provision of quality curative and preventative nutrition services through running eight RRTs and deployment of community outreach activities in the targeted areas in Idleb and rural Aleppo, as well as QRCS, will continue to implementing programmatic adjustment in the context of COVID-19 to protect health care providers, mitigate the risk of infection and ensure continuity of life-saving nutrition services as the followings: 1-Continuity of life-saving nutrition services particularly CMAM, micronutrient supplementation, and IYCF-E under guidance for adaptations in the context of COVID-19 through the deployment of eight mobile rapid response teams and each RRT will visit 3-4 communities weekly. 2- RRTs will provide MUAC screening, refer complicated SAM cases and provision of therapeutic for SAM and MAM cased among children 6-59 months and malnourished PLWs as in 29 communities including IDPs camps. 3- Provision of Maternal nutrition and appropriate IYCF-E counselling and messages for pregnant women and mothers. 4- Screen, referral children and PLWs with Medical problems. 5- 16 CHWs and one team leader will conduct community outreach activities promoting IYCF-E, Maternal nutrition, health, and WASH-related topics and massages, and Identify visual signs of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs during Nutrition screening based on NWS nutrition cluster and TWG recommendations in the context of COVID-19 using additional platforms such as mobile text messages, radio, TV, and social media to protect, promote and support IYCF-E. 6-Distribution of micronutrient supplementary to PLWs and children under 5 based on SoPs and nutrition cluster recommendations. 7-Conduct training on IYCF-E and CMAM programming in the context of COVID-19 for RRTs staff as well as identify visual signs of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs, referral pathway and COVID-19 pandemic. 8- Roll-out of a family MUAC approach for caregivers, PLW, and family members. 9- QRCS will conduct COVID 19 precaution during implementation through procuring protective personal equipment such as gloves, masks, sterilizers as well as staff will receive training on IPC and precaution measures. Also, QRCS will conduct online awareness sessions and distribute IEC materials via special channels in social media. 10- QRCS will coordinate with nutrition cluster, partners and local councils and coordinate with WASH cluster through the regular coordination between Nut. and WASH clusters if needed. During the project -12 months- period, QRCS will provide supportive supervision and on-job monitoring and training through community health leader, field project coordinator and project management based in Turkey, as well as QRCS, will provide equitable access and quality of nutrition services to the most vulnerable population among 57,395 children under 5 (28,655 boys and 28,740 girls) and 12,320 PLWs reaching 99,090 expected beneficiaries including (55,160 Female and 43,930 Male), with 1,413 disables people, 56,480 displaced population and overburdened and 42,610 host communities. All estimated caseload and a number of targeted beneficiaries determined based on the capacity of QRCS and previous project finding, achievement and results which reported to nutrition cluster via monthly 4Ws (for more information and 4Ws reports see Annexes attached to support document section on GMS

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing the protective environment, access to Child protection, comprehensive GBV support and empowerment for the most vulnerable group through Protection services, livelihood and income-generating opportunities. within widows' camps

description.narrative: MARAM Foundation will continue providing Protection services to the same 13 widow camps (where MF still has approved access to those camps Annex G) and will expand in services in the targeted area to include new GBV and CP activities and integrated ERL services. MF will deliver a strategic and multisectoral, multi-AoR including GBV and CP, Early Recovery and Livelihoods (ERL) clusters at 13 camps located in Syria Cross-border, matching Humanitarian Fund’s (SCHF’s) high priority locations (sub-districts of Dana, Harim) for boys, girls, women, elders and people with disabilities through mobile teams, MF will select project staff to match the BNFs types considering the culture and situation on the ground and try to balance between males and females staff as much as possible. MF was one of the first initiatives that establish and manage IDP camps in NWS. The camp is called “Olive Tree” now is called Atmeh camp. MF carries out different types of projects, including protection, education, food security and livelihoods, camp and shelters, WASH, and non-food distribution. During the years, MF delivered aid to more than 2 million people inside Syria and in the neighbouring countries. Also, MF is equipped with over 7 years of experience in providing protection services (CP, GBV, and general protection). Recently MF had the chance to implement GBV activities in 13 camps for widows, the project funded by CHF and shows a great positive impact on women and girls living in those camps. This project will benefit these high-priority areas by strengthening and enhancing child protection (CP) services, enhancing the quality of gender-based violence (GBV) services, prevent GBV, strengthening community resilience, and reducing socio-economic vulnerabilities. MF will consider Do No harm principles and guidelines and match with the widows' camps context to prevent any further harm. In light of the spread of COVID-19, MF during implementation will take into consideration all prevention procedures, guidelines of COVID-19 using GBVSC toolkit and MF COVID19 policy see (annexe I amp J). The project will be implemented in stages: 1, coordinating with the camp administration in order to secure a place for the project activities that consider the confidentiality amp safety of the activities. If no secured place, MF will create a tent as WGSS amp another one as a CFS in camps. 2, An elected committee of women amp girls including PWDs amp elderly women (in each camp), is going to participate in decision-making to determine the identity of the place, the type of activities, empowerment topics and future modality of their lifestyle. 3, 13 mobile teams in each location will be implementing the project’s activities (Using the Awareness Toolkit, the COVID Guidance and the MampE Toolkit as a reference), each team consists of a case manager (GBV, CP) who will provide CM both in-person and remotely, a PSS worker and female facilitator for each camp, and another male facilitator will be targeting men amp boys who live near the widows' camps, local authorities and councils. also, MF during this project will: provide vocational training and skills development to women in Babysitting and parenting, electronic literacy, knitting wool, manufacturing homemade detergents, sewing, and hairdressing. administering a startup business grant program for women. This project will benefit a total of 25000 individuals in the 13 camps: 6500 girls, 11000 women, 4500 boys, and 3000 men. MF will ensure the participation of all relevant stakeholders at all stages of the operations management cycle. MF will be responsible for the design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation (MampE), and closure phases. MF will manage the project, provide the contractual services, ensure the required coordination among clusters, and ensure high-quality results and efficient progress through the provision of capable programmatic specialized

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Explosive Ordnance Risk Education, Disposal, and Non-Technical Survey in Northwest Syria

description.narrative:
This project is consistent with HALO’s contribution to the 2021 HRP (ref: HSYR21-PRO-178454-1). It reflects lessons learned from HALO’s experience in northwest Syria since 2016 and is in consultation with the Mine Action Sub-Cluster (MASC) and the northwest Syria humanitarian cluster network in Gaziantep.
HALO will deliver a 12 month humanitarian mine action response to support 12,538 beneficiaries through direct implementation and support from an implementing partner (iMFAD). The project includes:
a) Explosive Ordnance Risk Education (EORE) b) EORE Trainer of Trainer (ToT) training c) Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) and d) Non-Technical Survey (NTS)
These activities will be conducted in selected sub-districts across opposition-controlled areas of Idleb and western Aleppo and across Turkish-administered areas of northern Aleppo. HALO will deliver EORE and ToT training in opposition-controlled areas and iMFAD will deliver EOD and NTS in Turkish-administered areas. EORE field staff will be trained to deliver community COVID-19 awareness messaging consistent with WHO guidance.
Explosive Risk Ordnance Education and Train the Trainer Training One five-person Community Liaison Team (CLT) under HALO will deliver 30-40 minute community-based risk education sessions to children and adults across Idleb, Harim and Jisr-Ash-Shugur districts. Content will be consistent with MASC key messaging. The CLT will also deliver training to Community Focal Points (CFPs) and NGO Focal Points across all humanitarian sectors to improve the integration and reach of risk education messaging. The total beneficiary target is 11,960 direct beneficiaries (11,730 EORE beneficiaries and 230 CFPs and NGO Focal Points). Beneficiary calculations are at Annex C.
Explosive Ordnance Disposal and Non-Technical Survey One five-person EOD/NTS team under iMFAD will destroy 105 items and complete 15 non-technical survey community reports across 22 communities throughout the duration of the project in the districts of A’zaz and Afrin of the Aleppo governorate, averaging one item of explosive ordnance per day. The team will also conduct NTS in explosive ordnance (EO) contaminated communities to assess minefields, cluster munition strike areas, IED fields, and areas densely contaminated with EO to better define these areas in terms of scale, hazard and impact on communities and to enable planning of future activities. The total beneficiary target is 578 direct EOD beneficiaries.
The project will be delivered by HALO field staff from their office in Kelly, Idleb and by iMFAD field staff in A’zaz, Aleppo. HALO and iMFAD’s offices will coordinate operations from Gaziantep and field staff will be supported directly by HALO staff in Amman and iMFAD staff in Balikesir. Lessons learned from previous projects as well current funding constraints have prompted HALO to restructure both programme and field offices to be leaner, more efficient and cost effective, adapting the number of staff to more effectively match the needs of the project size, requirements and the current funding limitations. The project comprises staff 20 funded at 100% (HALO: 9 iMFAD, 11) – all in Northwest Syria and 15 funded under shared arrangements (HALO: 10, iMFAD: 5). 24 of 35 staff are in Northwest Syria. This shared funding is principally through private unrestricted donations to HALO to be allocated to the project. The project organogram is at Annex F.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Empowering women and girls and enhancing access to GBV prevention services in Western rural of Aleppo.

description.narrative:
The project endeavors to implement complemented activities in the humanitarian field in western rural of Aleppo province. This intervention will strengthen permanent protection assistance and services in IDP sites through the establishment of facilities inside and/or in close proximity to IDP sites and make a contribution towards Life-saving humanitarian assistance and protection to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on underserved areas with high severity of needs depending on the expansion of the activities of two existing protection centers WGSS specialized in GBV in Atareb and Kafr Karmin villages. The project includes the following activities: - Forming of three mobile teams to provide of psychological first aid (PFA), information/awareness, individual and emergency case management support, life skills program, GBV services, referrals to GBV services and other services. The teams will cover the Daret Azza and Atareb sub-district in rural Aleppo in addition to the surrounding camps. (every sub-team will consist of two mobile teams, two social workers and case management workers). - Support the case management activities (Case fund) for 100 survivors. This assistance will be provided in kind and cash. The estimated amount for each beneficiary is 100 USD. Based on Cash Assistance in GBV Case Management Guidance Note June 2019.By GBV-sub cluster. - Engaging 1760 women and girls with vocational activities in WGSS and ten point in camps. - Establishment of eleven protection desks in camps inside and/or near IDP sites to provide specialized and non-specialized protection services, PSS support, Individual Protection Assistance and Emergency Case Fund in IDP sites. - Provide 550 men, women, girls and boys with disabilities reached with protection services to specialized and non-specialized services like (peer-support, awareness raising, skills development, PSS, case management and Ambassador's programme to increase PwD participation in humanitarian action).
This intervention will support 23,715 beneficiaries affected by the Syrian crisis (4982 men,8414 women, 4364 boys and 5955 girls, 125 men PWD, 125 women PWD, 150 boys PWD, 150 girls PWD) in Atareb and Daret Azza - sub-districts by promoting their accessibility to the protection assistance significantly. The project is designed to fit and be flexible to deal with conditions of constant changes and continuous of flows of IDPs who move between several locations. Also, the project team will ensure data protection, confidentiality at all stages, protocols of information sharing and acquiring informed consent from beneficiaries. The project activities will be in line with Protection Cluster Recommendations, SOPs, Inclusive COVID-19 response - NWS Disability - TWG on Inclusion Guidance Note April 2020 and GBV SC guidance note on GBV service provision in the time of COVID-19 such as Hand sanitizing when conducting the sessions/ Gathering of five beneficiaries per session and social distance/Measure the temperature for each beneficiary as a precaution/ Plan has been put for online sessions/ Put awareness posters about Corona disease during sessions.
MASRRAT has been in the protection sector for seven years. MASRRAT is a focal point to provide GBV services in Jebel Seman district. This project will complement the ongoing UNFPA project through covering of more area of intervention in Jebel Samaan ,where the two teams will work together under the same management and technical support, also the project will support the centers by vocational activity. Each outreach team will be accompanied by a case manager who identifies the cases and coordinates with the GBV technical supervisor on UNFPA project to receive the cases in WGSS centers.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Integrated Protection Prevention and Response Services to The Most Vulnerable People in NW Syria Including Individuals in the Widows Camps of Aleppo

description.narrative: This project aims to provide integrated protection services targeting the most vulnerable people in Idleb (Kelly, Armanaz, and Qourqeena) and Aleppo (A’zaz, Aghtrin, Jarablus, and Atareb) in the most severe locations with a high need for protection services, along with interfering in the Widows’ Camps (WCs) of A’zaz (Aisha compound, Mulham home and village), Aghtrin (Makkah compound), and Jarablus Al Amal Village, (Annex 18 – Widows camps data) reaching a total of 69,100 BNFs as follow: IRD aims to support IDPs and HC population with CP, GBV prevention and, GP response services participating in the three strategic objectives as follow: 1-Protection services extension in Kelly protection center and expansion of Child Friendly Space “CFS” in Azaz, along with establishing two protection desks in the IDPs sites of Qourqeena and Atareb to provide the GP services including: Awareness raising sessions about GP concerns, including COVID-19. Recreational PSS sessions targeting boys and girls using UNICEF recreational kits. Providing referrals to protection and non-protection services. Provision of Individual Protection Assistance IPA to most vulnerable cases of MWBG. Establishment and support a total of 8 committees and conduct a monthly basis community consultation to participate in project monitoring and implementation. Conducting monthly Protection Monitoring “PM” and Child Protection Status Monitoring “CPSM” surveys in 16 communities in Idleb and Aleppo. Providing awareness-raising sessions and legal counseling on Civil Status Documentation “CSD” and HLP. Providing RE awareness sessions targeting IDPs, HC, and returnees. IRD in coordination with the protection cluster, will design a tool to measure the access and inclusion of PwDs in IDP sites along with issuing 5 bi-monthly narrative reports after analyzing the related data. Providing IPA, referrals, and legal counseling in (WCs) of A’zaz and Aghtrin. 2- CP services through expansion of Kelly protection center and extension of CFS in A’zaz, and Armanaz, also, to interfere in (WCs) of Azaz, Aghtrin and Jarablus as follow: Provision of Child Protection case management (CP CM). Supporting CPCs to prevent and respond to CP needs. Conduct PSS group activities for displaced and vulnerable children. Training frontline workers on (Child Protection Minimum Standards “CPMS”, Child Protection in Emergencies “CPiE”,Child Safeguarding “CSG”, Safe Identification and Referral “SIR”, Case Management “CM” and CM supervisory) Conduct awareness-raising sessions on CP through multiple channels at the community level. Parenting program targeting MW. Support most vulnerable children, including CwDs, with 3D printed assistive items. Provide awareness-raising sessions, integrated CM, and PSS to children in (WCs) in Jarablus, Aghtrin and Azaz. 3- GBV activities will be delivered through the extension of WGSS in A’zaz and expansion of WGSS in Aghtrin and Jarablus to provide income generation component as follows: GBV CM for women and girls’ survivors at risk with delivering case funds. Focused PSS counseling to women and girls Referral of GBV survivors to protection and non-protection services GBV training to frontline workers (CM, referral, GBV basics, GBV Standard Operation Procedures SOPs, facilitation skills, gender-based violence information management system plus “GBVIMS+”) and small project training for BNFs Provision of GBV awareness-raising sessions Vocational training for women and girls. Structured Activities including life skills and PSS. Young mothers club targeting the age interval of 10-19 years. Robotic life skills sessions. Provision of income-generating opportunities for women in WGSS and (WCs) Safety audit in WCs All activities is subject to COVID-19 prevention measures enabling to shift the implementation to online modality.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance access to life-saving community-based protection services (GBV MA) for the Women, girls, and other vulnerable for IDPs and host communities in WGSSs and widows camps in three locations in NWS.

description.narrative: WSA runs three WGSS in Hazano, KafrTakarim, and Kafrlucin in Idleb, since 2018, and planining to continue implementing activities through providing protection services for women and girls affected by the crisis, including GBV survivors Hazano WGSS is funded through HF and contributes to the promotion of services and measures of MA and quality GBV providing services to prevent and reduce the risks of GBV and COVID in the mentioned location, with the GBV SC amp MA SC Guidelines. For this WGSS we are proposing to continue providing specialized GBV services, Case Management, and specialized individual PSS Case workers will follow up with the WampG-GBV survivors. In addition to providing case fund to GBV survivors in accordance with the GBV SC Cash SOPs. service and referrals to other services according to the referral paths that are shared by the sub-clusters and creating a service mapping through coordination with actors in the area, continuously updated. Preventive activities, such as life skills (My safety my wellbeing), recreational activities, GBV awareness raising (GBV-SC toolkit), and Covid related awareness (WHO tools For the other two WGSSs in KafrTakarim and Kaferluci, which are funded by UNFPA, different tyoes of GBV servicers including both response and prevention services are provided. In this project, new activities will be added in the three proposed WGSS with the aim to enhance the protection and empowerment of women and girls, namely: 1-conducting vocational trainings for WampG, such as hairdressing, sewing, Microsoft Office programs, and ..etc. based on needs,400 WampG will be targeted in the three sites 2-Providing Individual Protection Assistance (IPA) to vulnerable women and girls According to specific criteria(widows and divorced, women-headed households elderly-headed households households with persons with disabilities(PwD) newly arrived displaced persons without shelter)total of 100$ 3 - 5 widow camps will be targeted to provide a package of life-saving services to empower adolescent girls and their mothers including:safety audit activity to assess and address risk factors related to protecting women and girls from GBV in camps. Awareness sessions on GBV Life skills programs for women and girls Connecting male children to services according to referral pathways to child protection The camps that WSA will target are Dar-Al Eiman- Kelly, Aa'esha - Foah, AL BER and Taqwa and al amal Village -Qah and Mothers of the Believers - Harim. Services will be provided to widows within the WGSSs or activities halls in camps, according to the situation of each camp and the type of the service In case of an emergency situation, WSA will use the Protection Cluster Emergency Response Package to Provide emergency response for WampG: PFA, referrals, registration. 4-providing small grants for 50 women out of the 400 in training to start a small project with the aim of generating income and economic independence for them women and girls in WGSSs and camps As per specific criteria: -Survivors of GBV specially widows, divorced and survivors withPwD -Females headed households The other part of the criteria will look the performance of the participant in the training period and will include: Commitment during the training period minimum 80% of the sessions -Adapting the necessary skills in the selected profession -Having a project idea in line wi Having a project idea in line with the market need on average 850$per case Capacity building activities will include training and refresher sessions on PSEA to all WSA staff in the three locations.Trainings for non-specialized GBV service providers in Hazzano, on GBV basic concepts focusing on health actors, cash and voucher distributors workers, and early recovery actors According to the latest developments regarding the global pandemic of Coronavirus, the provision of GBVservices will be in line with the WHO guidelines, and following the guidance GBV-SC during COVID.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Increasing access to quality and specialized CP,GBV services in Dana Sub-District.

description.narrative:
*This project is Multi-AOR Project CP/GBV. SoP intending to expand its provision of integrated community-based protection interventions and provision of life-saving protection activities to conflict-affected populations across Northwest Syria. The Project aims to enhance the prevention and mitigation of protection risks, and respond to protection needs providing GBV,CPservices to most vulnerable PiN with a focus on Women, Girls,Boys, and youth(14-24) (including PwDs), prioritizing critical gaps in life-saving protection services, and designed to be people-centered project supports self-sustainable protective environment for the most vulnerable IDPs,in targeted Community and camps. SoP will support existing WGSS and CFS center in Dana Subdistrict (accessible for PwDs) and targeting /4/ surrounding Widow’s Camps (Camps Names and Access permission in the attachments) by establishing static help desk in each camp and targeting the camps by outreach teams as well.
SoP aiming to provide the following activities: GBV: 1-Case Management for the most vulnerable Women and Girls , case fund will be allocated on the budget to support the needs of the most critical cases as per Protection cluster and SCs relevant SOP and guidance. 2-Awareness raising sessions through the mobile team in 4 selected Widow’s camps and Dana Sub-district. 3-Life skills sessions for Women and Girls (inside the static help desks in the camps). 4- Income-generating vocational training for the Women and Girls ( in the nearby WGSS Center). 5-Periodical Safety Audits in the camps by the outreach team. 6-Establish /4/ Women networks, /1/ in each camp. CP: 1-Case Management for Children inside and outside camps ( With a focus on the children who aged out and separated from their care givers in the Widow’s camps ) case fund will be allocated on the budget to support the needs of the most critical cases as per Protection cluster and SCs relevant SOP and guidance (Inter-Agency Guidelines for Case Management amp Child Protection will be applied). 2- Structured PSS sessions for children in camps and the CFS. 3- Awareness raising activities for children, parents, humanitarian workers,community members and camps managment on key child protection concerns, focusing on following topics (Child Labour, FTR, Basic CP, Child Rights) Using UNICEF IEC materials. 4-Center-Based and outreach parenting skills sessions, using IRC Parenting Skills Manual.
By that the static help desks in the camps will be acting as primary portal to Share information and enroll/refer beneficiaries to the available services.
Information/Data will be collected under each activity as per the SoP’s internal reporting mechanism while taking into consideration proper data disaggregation and MoVs, Monthly figures will be shared with Clusters and SCs through 4Ws , Case Management tool and other reporting channels.
Covid-19: SOP is member of Health cluster and receiving frequent updates on the pandemic situation , as for all running projects COVID-19 prevention measures and related recommendations are applied among all activities (center based and outreach).
PwDs Inclusion : SOP note for inclusion of PWDs into the activities attached

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Life-saving protection mitigation and prevention support for unaccompanied and separated children and families vulnerable to separation

description.narrative: Through this project, SARD intends to support a number of unaccompanied and separated children and families vulnerable to separation through continuation and extension of its specialized and unspecialized protection services which specifically target sensitive child protection issues such as family separation, early child marriage, child labor and recruitment to military services. Through its emergency centres/ Child-Friendly Spaces (CFS) in A’zaz, SARD provides unaccompanied and separated children with critical life-saving protection services including shelter, emergency and accelerated learning support and PSS, and foster placement. Outside the centres, through its referral system in coordination with the Protection cluster, SARD’s Mobile Case Management team identifies child protection cases and renders or refers specialized and unspecialized protection services. The project is innovative and is an alternative approach of child protection providing multi-sectoral integrated response to the UASC in the emergency shelter and providing alternative care with particular effort to place the UASC in foster families. Foster families and other families vulnerable to child separation are accompanied throughout the project with provision of dedicated services to favour family placement and prevent family separation During the project, the following will be implemented : - 1 emergency shelters will be running and equipped to host UASC in emergency situation. In the center, all services are provided to the UASC : each child will receive a full kit (1 in summer and 1 in winter) that includes clothes, shoes, hygiene material and products, Each child is assigned a dedicated space for sheltering him ensuring safety and security is provided 24/7. In the center, the UASC will be also provided with all the necessary food (special dietary is provided depending on the child needs, age and conditions), necessary environmental hygiene (hair cut, disinfection of the premises, Covid 19 prevention, basic environmental health care. The innovation being the project will provide all the services, integrated and multi-sectoral, to ensure the aulity of the delivery and the best accountability to the children benefiting the project. - provision of protection services to children and foster families or families vulnerable to separation, through mobile team visit and assessments. This action will aim at providing all necessary emergency support to families to keep the children in the household securing access to basic needs. As such, SARD will refer the family in emergency needs to other project implemented by SARD with provision of basic needs and even livelihood/income generating opportunities to secure access to income to cover emergency basic needs (under other donors). These activities are implemented by 2 mobile teams (of 4 persons), 1 child protection mobile team in Azaz looking at UASC needs in each location and 1 PSS mobile team (of 4 persons) covering providing all the PSS supports and requirement to both UASC and parenting program as well. - Parenting Program: SARD facilitates a parenting program to train caregivers on Child Protection, PSS and dealing with their children’s behavior. Separated and Unaccompanied children boys and girls shall be identified and registered in child protection information management system and their parents traced for reunification. Reflecting on the current situation in northwest Syria, there are many cases of separated and unaccompanied children identified but their families not yet traced, SARD will work closely with the care givers to ensure that conflict affected children boys and girls are protected from abuse, violence, and exploitation through organising meeting with care givers to discuss the child protection issues in the communities to come up with best ways to protect the affected children.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Continuation the enhancement of the protective environment and access to comprehensive protection support (GBV, CP, and Legal consultation) and empowerment of vulnerable affected population including women and girls in widows’ camps in NWS.

description.narrative: Starting from the priorities identified by the protection cluster and sub-clusters, and as per the findings of the need’s assessments conducted in the last period, SEMA, and its partners HRO and SANAD, under SCHF, seek to provide life-saving protection prevention and response services. SEMA and SANAD through the existing two CFSs in Afrin and Al-Bab communities (Amal Centers) under SCHF until 14 July 2021, will continue the provision of CP prevention and response services. Activities include CP case management, structured PSS, parenting skills, awareness, identification and referral through static and mobile teams, SANAD team will provide Special need rehabilitation program (SNR) for CwDs, and parenting skill for their caregivers. 4 CP outreach teams will provide awareness raising sessions, recreational activities and identification and referral for at risk CP cases, 3 Case specialists in each CFS will continue providing a comprehensive CP case management. 1CM supervisor in each CFS will continue to supervise the quality of case management and PSS Structured services. Already existed 2 community committees in Albab and Sharran, will continue their roles in raising awareness of affected communities on CP concerns, contagion risks of COVID-19 and precautionary measures. Total number of beneficiaries 16481 (M :1131 ,W:1431 , B:6960, G:6959) HRO, under SCHF, will continue running the already existing two community centers in (Afrin, Aleppo, and Darkoush, Idleb), to support vulnerable host communities and IDPs prioritizing targeting two Widows’s Camps in Darkoush (Aytam Al-Sham, Ommahat Almoamineen) with high quality life-saving GBV, CP, and legal consultation on CSD and HLP including case fund with more emphasis on cases identified by case management to be under child labour and/or exposed to be separated of their mothers in widows camps, in addition to micro-grant to ensure income-generating and economic independence for most vulnerable women including widows in widows camp. 2 GBV case manager, and 2 CP case manager in Syria and technical team in Turkey will ensure quality CM and PSS services. 8 outreach workers will conduct structured PSS, and the establishment of women committees in widows’ camps to support women's affairs and engagement in decision-making and addressing women and children concerns, women committees and camps manager will be trained on GBV and CP basic prevention and response, communication skills, and suicide prevention. At-risk women will be supported with micro-grant to promote their self-independence and mitigation of any potential GBV risks. Community awareness is raised on essential topics of GBV, CP, Legal information especially on CSD and HLP, in addition to COVID-19 and PSEA. Total number of beneficiaries 9197 (M:1994, W:3471, B:1436, and G:2296). SEMA and HRO will continue reporting to CPMT, PMTF, GBV SC (safety audit in widows camps). SEMA, under other grants, continues complementing Health, Nutrition, Physiotherapy, and MHPSS strengthening internal and external referral pathways. Same for HRO who provides MHPSS under private fund along with the protection services. HRO MHPSS team will provide suicide prevention, selfcare and PFA-COVID-19 training for project field team (SEMA, SANAD, and HRO). Activities will be adapted according to COVID-19 consequent restriction of movements, and in line with (Guidance Note on GBV and CP Service Provision during the time of COVID-19) and (Ethical Closure Matrix), COVID-19 precautionary measures in line with WHO standards will be applied in face-to-face activities. Women and girls benefited from GBV services, and caregivers of children benefited from CP services who are in need for legal awareness and consultation will be referred internally to GP/ qualified and experienced lawyers. Findings of PM reports on protection needs and gaps, will strengthen the advocacy efforts on GBV, CP, and legal awareness, and during PM interviews cases will be referred accordingly

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of humanitarian CCCM, and WASH assistance for the most vulnerable IDPs in ‎Harim district.

description.narrative: To improve IDP sites by ensuring safe and dignified living conditions of vulnerable conflict-affected ‎HHs and to stress on prevention measures of COVID 19, BRD in partnership with MSO are planning to respond to1930 HHs, 12560 IDPs (2299 M, 2727 W, 3556 B, 3978 ‎G and 71 PWD) in 9 camps (Al Wafaa, Reef Aleppo Al Janobi, Jabal Al-Hos, Ghetaa Al Rahma2, Nour Al Houda, Al Forkan, Al Sufara'a. Al Amal and Al Khan). Project interventions are designed to achieve Cluster and Strategic Objectives outlined in ASO1 and ASO3 by involving stakeholders, proposed interventions will provide lifesaving humanitarian assistance to most vulnerable people, emphasizing underserved areas with high severity needs. Project will also reduce burden on population especially women, children and PWD to secure clean water, improving their hygiene, prevent of COVID 19 protecting them against fire. ‎Based on BRD experience in grant management and implementing listed activities within this proposal, partnership with MSO will contribute to BRD’s capacity in grant management and implement activities on a field basis where BRD will directly supervise MSO implementation of activities in addition to its role in MampE. Besides, MSO has a team of specialized engineers in implementing activities of water and sewer networks and construction of water tanks, given that MSO has proven previous experience in these activities, in which MSO successfully implemented 3 previous projects which included WASH activities and infrastructure, NFI distribution and hygiene promotion activities in more than 50 different camps. additionally, MSO has a field team with extensive experience in project operation area that will be with added value to project where experiences shall be exchanged between partners. WASH: In parallel to WASH cluster strategy in the allocation paper, the aim is to reduce the huge reliance on the costly non-sustainable direct provision water trucking, desludging, etc. towards a more cost-effective cheaper and more efficient response, this is planned to be achieved through connecting the targeted camps and informal settlement to existing nearby water and sanitation system. Furthermore, through this project. To achieve better response and make most of capabilities of each team, work will be divided, BRD will: Establishment a sewage network for 9 targeted camps. Connecting 9 camps to nearby sewer networks. Connecting existing sanitation facilities. Providing a water station with all necessary equipment and supplies. Conducting HP campaign in targeted camps, through ‎trained mobile team on personal hygiene and COVID-19 prevention, considering prevention ‎measures and social distancing. While it will benefit from great experience of MSO in implementing similar projects, MSO will: Construct communal water ‎tanks in targeted camps. Connect water ‎tanks with water sources through construction of water ‎network from available sources. Establish water networks and link it to high tanks. Operation and maintenance cost for a total period of 6 months. Ensure proper water quantity and quality are delivered to most vulnerable people residing in camps.‎ On average 35 Lt/d/ will be provided while during Summer season (Jul, Aug, Sep) as recommended by WASH Cluster, IDPs will have access up to 40 lt/p/d. CCCM: BRD in cooperation with MSO will provided training for camp management on fire ‎prevention, mitigation, and response measures. Establish fire response committees in camps Its ‎responsibility is to develop a system to contain fires and mitigate their severity and risks. Committee ‎will be responsible for training staff, including camp guards and people involved in use of fire ‎extinguishers, and how to deal with fires if they occur. Conducting awareness campaigns and sessions for all camp residents about dangers of fire, taking all ‎safety and security measures, especially during winter season, and lighting the heating in a safe way ‎within tents

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: An integrated and complementary approach to support the most vulnerable persons with improved access to food security and WASH services.

description.narrative:
Under WASH amp FSL, Violet (VO) is proposing a complementary, integrated, amp multisectoral 10 months project to address WASH amp FSL needs of the most vulnerable. The project was designed based on the need assessment amp clusters guidance with the following activities:
- FSL (SO2) VO will provide lifesaving assistance by the blanket distribution of regular cash for food (60 $ / HH $50 amp the value of $10 in the local currency preferred by recipients) for 783 food-insecure IDPs HHs (3915 Ind) inhabiting Mashhad Rouhin camps in Dana Sub-district over 8 rounds to improve their access to diversified amp fresh food amp increase their purchasing power without being affected by the devaluation of the local currency. The aim is to contribute to sustaining minimum food consumption needs of the vulnerable IDPs. By doing so, access to diverse foods will also strengthen their immune system amp mitigate the negative effects of COVID-19 on their socio-economic. Besides cash, VO will distribute soap kits (750 G of soap/HH) in accordance with WASH cluster recommendation) to improve BNFs access to COVID-19 prevention means. Cash modality is selected to provide flexibility for BNFs to buy their needs, but also to provide assistance in a dignified way. To avoid harm, VO confirmed the viability of the local market to meet the increased demand. However, VO will conduct RNA prior to distributions to verify the availability amp accessibility to the functioning markets. The cash value was designed to cover approx. 70% of the daily intake (1550 Kcal/ person/ day) as per the FSL guidance. It is reflective of 70% of the SMEB food-only proxy basket. Cash for food will complement SR - WASH activities in the targeted camps
- WASH (SO1, SO2) The component aims to address the WASH needs of both IDPs amp HC who are living in both settings (in-camp amp off-camp) through the provision of comprehensive WASH services by the WASH activities below to be implemented in the camps in Mashhad Rouhin amp Bab El Hawa locations: 1.Provision of 35 liters of drinking amp chlorinated water for 15,470 BNFs inhabiting 5 IDPs camps for 3 months. The water quality will be insured by conducting the water tests by VO's monitors. Moreover, VO will coordinate with ACU to ensure the quality of the water sources 2.Rehabilitation of boreholes, water stations, amp water networks inside the targeted camps. The water systems will be equipped with PV Solar energy systems to minimize the water system operating costs amp to ensure the sustainability amp long-term impact of the project. 3. Distribution of Hygiene kits to the IDPs inhabiting the camps to improve the BNFs access to most essential hygiene supplies. Moreover, VO will implement campaigns to disseminate awareness messages related to COVID-19 (RCCE), the importance of preventive measures, amp hygiene promotion. 4.Solid waste management amp desludging septic tanks in 4 camps amp for 7 months in Al Emam Camp while Shafak covers its needs till end of June WASH activities will complement White Hands, amp PIN's GFA in part of the target camps On the other hand, VO is planning to conduct the necessary rehabilitation of the water system in Al Abzimo Community to improve the IDPs amp HC in Abzimo in western Aleppo access to clean water, but also to reduce required water trucking amp lack of access to clean amp safe drinking water. To ensure the intervention impact amp sustainability, VO will equip the water station with PV Solar Power system to minimize the operating costs. Furthermore, VO will support the community to establish the Tariff system amp re-activate the cost recovery mechanism to ensure an effective response
During Project Implementation, VO will ensure COVID-19 preventive measures are applied to avoid exposing the communities to harm
The proposed project

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide lifesaving WASH and SNFI assistance through camps infrastructure improvements and increase community capacity to support IDPs sites

description.narrative:
In response to the costly and short-term water supply in northwest Syria and to reinforce the most urgent life-saving interventions, WATAN aims to enhance the long-term WASH infrastructure and provide an SNFI package and direct live-saving assistance. This improvement targets host communities and IDPs located in Dana and Maaret Tamsrin, which located in Northwest Syria 'nowadays experience a funding shortfall in water and sanitation services. (OCHA, Report No. 25, 2021). To this aim, the planned intervention will respond to the needs of 68393 individuals (41393 IDP's and 27000 residents - 12573 men, 15043 women, 19176 boys, and 21601 girls) through the following strategies:
The expansion of the water network and introduction of a solar energy system in the water station to reduce the monthly operational cost by almost 65% in Kafr Deryan. This approach will benefit a population of 47.000 individuals (8460 men,10340 women, 13160 boys, and 15040 girls), A cost recovery system will be established in the community by supporting the OampM cost for 5 months with descending coverage (100% for the first month, then 80%, 60%, 40%, and 20% by the fifth month) to ensure a smooth exit strategy. afterward, WATAN will conduct end-line survey for the water station using the tool by WASH cluster. Water infrastructure for 9 camps to ensure at least 35 L/captia/day of safe water for drinking and personal hygiene, which will be supported by the solar system to reduce the operational cost to zero. In total four solar systems (one has been installed, one in Kafr Daryan community will support the community and 4 camps, and two in camps to support 4 camps) will benefit a population of 68393 individuals. In addition, Kafr Deryan community will be covered through the rehabilitation and expansion of the sewer network. Rehabilitation and installation of the sewer networks in camps to ensure safe access to sanitation infrastructure. Shelter in camps activities in 8 camps with paving and road gravelling within the camps, lighting the camps, tents gravelling, replacement and NFI CRI items kits distribution will be complementary services from WATAN. Alnamothaji Althani camp will receive a provision generating set, construction of pumping room, operational support cost, SWM activities, Hygiene kits distribution, and hygiene promotion. Special attention to the concerns related to the COVID-19 outbreak through two rounds of distribution of hygiene kits in the camps to support 21393 individuals. Hygiene education and awareness sessions related to COVID-19 prevention, promoted by female professionals under the protection specialist's supervision.
With a sustainable and innovative solar system to ensure IDPs and the host community's hygienic needs, WATAN is aware of the scope of the solar system during winter. As a response, during the rehabilitation period, water trucking service will be available for 3 months, and water quality monitoring will be applied to ensure that the FRC at the user level is at least 0.2 mg/l. On the other hand, and to ensure there are enough distribution points, WATAN will install water tanks (1000 L) water ground reservoir (150 m3) in Taiba City camp.
Besides, during the rehabilitation period, desludging activities will be available for 3 months. The project will include the installation of latrine blocks in 8 camps, maintenance of the existing latrines, and installation of PWD latrines. Also, WATAN will support the OampM activities of the latrines through regular cleaning by workers who will be hired from the same camps. Regarding solid waste management, there will be a daily basis intervention for the 9 camps that will include waste removal trucks and waste removal workers. The collected waste will be dumped at informal dumping sites in Dana, and Maaret Tamsrin sub-district.
This intervention will address the HRP Strategic Objective 1 and 3 ,and it is directly linked with the ASO 1 and 3.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Igniting Resiliency among the Conflict-Affected Syrian Population in north Syria through the establish renewable energy modalities (solar system) for the water stations and supporting WASH services (1)

description.narrative: The project is designed to respond to the WASH needs of 40061 people (Men: 8391, Women: 9120, Girls: 11050, Boys: 11500),( 16,709 IDPs , 22,769 hosted people, and returnees 583 ) with 315 people of them are people with disabilities, to respond to their protracted needs by ensuring the good access to sustainable WASH service ,The project is designed to respond to the needs of IDPs, Returnees, and hosted people, stayed Western Marj Akhdar, Mreimin, Bsheiriyeh - Bello, Hamama - Kafr Debbin communities and Engineers camp1, which located in Jisr-Ash-Shugur district , Darkosh,Jisr-Ash-Shugur , Janudiyeh subdistricts/Idleb governorate to cover their needs by delivering humanitarian WASH supplies and services to most vulnerable people: men, women, boys, and girls will benefit from the activities which aim to increase access to sustainable water, sanitation, and environmental hygiene solutions, the project will be transferred the water station from working by fuel to work by a hygiene system most of it solar energy .also SECD have connecting Mreimin water network to the planned camp “ Engineers camp1”and during this project the IDPs in the camp will access to suitable water resources .SECD is planning also to establish a proper solid waste management system since these communities are suffering from the accumulation of garbage on the streets which is a known cause for the spreading of Leishmania in it. Through this project, SECD is planning to support the targeted communities with the following activities: -Installation of the solar power system to turn the operating system of the water stations: Western Marj Akhdar 90 HP, Mreimin and Engineers camp1 60 HP, Bsheiriyeh 70 HP, Hamama - Kafr Debbin 100 HP into a hybrid power system as an environmental-friendly and cost-effective solution, conducting water safety plan, and establishing cost recovery system to ensure the suitability of the project. -Distribution of 4000 consumable hygiene kits for 2000 vulnerable families of most vulnerable people (two rounds). each family will receive 2 hygiene kits of the same components during the life cycle of the project. the component of the HKs is linked with (WASH Cluster - Hygiene Kits v2 final - COVID 19). -Conducting 9 hygiene promotion campaigns, SECD will target the entire community with at least COVID 19 awareness. The hygiene promotion campaign will focus on Coronavirus-2019, SECD will adhere to the recommendation of the WASH cluster in the implementation of the hygiene promotion and will focus on using the recommended methods, also during these campaigns SECD will distribute PSEA for beneficiaries to increase the knowledge and access to PSEA reporting hotline Supporting sanitation works which include but not limited to : -Provision and installation of 2050 garbage bins 0.1m3 size for targeted communities. -Rehabilitation 3 solid waste trucks and providing one. -Support SWM unit with salaries and fuel for 6 months, and uniforms for the workers, masks, gloves to protect the workers of coronavirus-2019 in this service with Conducting solid waste campaigns to encourage people to participate in this humanitarian effort. -Rehabilitation of the sewer system which includes but is not limited to Rehabilitation and extending of Sewer system network ( (HDPE 30cm diameter ):800m,- (HDPE80 cm diameter ):600m. SECD will be in a close position with the local council, the beneficiaries, the IDPs, and the host community and will involve them in all the project stages from the planning till the closure of the project to adhere to the community engagement approach by inviting them to regular FGDs and open all the channels to receive their feedback, complaints, and opinions. SECD Coordinated with GOAL and Water Unit in Darkoush, GOAL informed us that the provided support to Western Marj Akhdar, Bsheiriyeh – Bello, and Mreimin is secured till the end of May 2020 and to avoid duplication in supporting Water Unit staff

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Promote the resilience of the most vulnerable people in Jarablus and IDP camps affected by the Syrian crisis through live-saving activities in the WASH sector.

description.narrative: In general, 60% of the population in affected communities relying on alternatives to piped water and often unsafe water supply modalities to meet their water needs, the WASH infrastructure and service provision in many parts of Syria require significant repair and operational support. With the anticipation of continued community transmission of COVID-19, mainstreaming COVID-19 response throughout all regular WASH activities is crucial to mitigate risks. The project aims to assist 96,909 individuals ( Host and IDP) living in Jarablus city and IDP camps ( Al Jabal, Al Malab, Abo Shehab, Jubanat, Al Malaab, Al Masref, Khalawy, Bakres, Al koureieh, Maskaneh) the existing water system depends on two water boreholes receive the water from the Euphrates river connected to the main water network through vertical pumps pumping the water to the city and rural sides. The power source is electricity from the national grid supported by a private Turkish company, the yielding water from these two boreholes is very low and un efficient, the local council has to run the water pumps 20 hours per day to cover 50% of the needs in the city only (20 liter at max), the other 50% of the houses and the IDPs in the surrounding camps depend on the water trucking which consider unsafe and expensive based on the families' income. The operating cost covered from the local council's income, zero water reaches to the IDPs camps because of the low boreholes efficiency, this is due to the expired life of the filtering boreholes (these boreholes established since 20 years ago), the high cost paid by the local council to provide water to the city only push the local council to neglect the other services such as rehabilitation of the sanitation lines, and solid waste management in the city and camps. IYD, by establishing a drinking water treatment plant on the Euphrates River and connect it to the existing water stations in Jarablus, and support the operation cost for Jarablus water stations and Al Jabel camp water station aims to improve humanitarian response in the WASH sector based on priority humanitarian needs by focusing on the most urgent needs which lead to cover the gaps and deliver WASH supplies and services to improve the hygienic and daily practices for the most vulnerable people In Jarablus city and surrounding IDPs camps, the project links to the SCHF first objective and to the 2nd objective of WASH cluster this plant will withdraw the water from the river and pass it through two filtration units ( two lines of filtration units each line consists of one sedimentation block and four sand filters with 35 m3 flow per filter the total flow of the line is 4 X 35 m3 ), the filtration units will be connected to the chlorination unit, the outlet of the chlorination unit will connect to the main groundwater tank 250 m3, IYD will connect this main water tank to the main water network through three horizontal water pumps, the total flow 3 x 180 m3/h. By operating the water treatment plant, the clean water will reach the city and IDP camps and the operation cost will be decreased by about 50% based on the required operating hours. The functioning of the water stations and the flow of the water through the water network will provide good conditions to operate the sanitation system in the city which will make the need to rehab all damaged lines is critical and required, IYD will rehabilitate the sanitation systems by repairing the damaged lines and clean the blocked lines and reconstructs the inspection pits in Jarablus city and AL Jabel camp. The project focus will ensure appropriate water, sanitation, and handwashing standards in IDP sites setting, hand hygiene promotion. IYD will establish water units in the supported water stations and provide them with OampM training, and work closely with the local council to establish the tariff system for sustain.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by supporting health authorities to implement and carry out contact tracing of probable cases as well as their contacts

description.narrative: The proposed intervention will contribute to reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by supporting local health system to implement and carry out contact tracing of probable cases as well as their contacts in Luhansk oblast GCA. The project will focus on the strengthening PHC level in Luhansk GCA by identifying main gaps in the current setting for efficient contact tracing taking into account specificities of the region affected by the conflict (i.e. lack of internet and mobile connection, lack of family doctors in rural locations, population aged 60+, insufficient communication and coordination between different healthcare levels) by providing methodological, logistics, material and HR support for creation of the contact tracing mechanism and for its implementation in the area by insuring daily data collection and rapid exchange of information with relevant authorities. Taking into account the duration of the project and the scope – 15 PHC centers for each district in the region – MdM will focus first on districts where confirmed cases will be identified, to cover an estimated 5 districts during the project duration. The number of districts can be revised based on the epidemiological situation in the region. With partner PHC centers MdM will sign specific MoUs and sub-grant agreements in order to enhance their logistics and HR capacities to reach the most isolated communities.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for conflict affected vulnerable and disabled older women and men in settlements located in the 5km zone in the GCAs locations of Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts.

description.narrative:
Ukraine had its first confirmed case of COVID-19 on 3rd March, 2020. As of 9th April, the country has had 1,892 confirmed cases, including in the conflicted affected areas of Donestska and Luhanska, and 57 deaths, with many more suspected cases likely undetected due to a lack of access to testing. The daily rate of new cases per day has been increasing, the spread of the virus has caused major concern among the population in the country, especially for older men and women who are most at risk.
Around 23% of the nation is above the age of 60, a similar percentage to that of Italy, the country that currently has the highest absolute number of mortalities caused by the virus, despite a more sophisticated health system than in places such as Ukraine. Over 80% of people who have died from COVID-19 in China were aged 60 and over and emerging data from the outbreak in Italy suggests an even more stark pattern by age. COVID-19 fatality rate also increases with pre-existing conditions such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic respiratory disease and hypertension. This highlights the correlation between COVID-19 severity and other medical conditions and complex needs, such as a disability that are highly related with old-age.This in addition to these vulnerable groups limited financial resources and access to basic hygiene items, food and health services in areas of Ukraine already compromised by conflict is especially concerning.
Whilst the nation as a whole faces extreme challenges from the health, economic and social consequences of this virus, humanitarian agencies are particularly concerned about its impact in Donetska and Luhanska Oblasts, which are affected by the protracted conflict with already overstretched health systems. Older people constitute a third (36%) of the conflict affected population in eastern Ukraine, reaching 41% in areas closest to the LoC. People with disabilities account for 12% of those in need, again with increased numbers closest to the LoC, most likely due to their increased isolation or reliance on others, limited physical mobility, poor economic resources, and their emotional attachment to property and assets, all of which inhibits their ability to move out of these areas.
This project builds on previous and current multi-sectoral humanitarian interventions implemented by HelpAge International in Ukraine, to provide direct support to conflict affected older women and men, including those with disabilities, who are most at risk from the effects of COVID-19, through Psychosocial Support (PSS ) activities, Home-Based Care (HBC) for the most vulnerable households, the provision of COVID-19 adapted hygiene kits and food packages, and the dissemination of age-friendly information materials on how to combat the virus.
The HBC activities will be implemented by existing HelpAge trained community-based volunteers, including in COVID-19 awareness and safety measures, who will safely conduct outreach visits while minimizing social contact and incorporating do-no harm practices to at least 2000 vulnerable older women and men, and persons with disabilities located in 17 of the 53 prioritised settlements of Donetsk and Luhansk. These locations are considered to be in high need and be the most isolated and hard to reach areas with limited services and infrastructure, near to the line of contact. The HBC services provides support to promote greater levels of Independent living capacity, reduce isolation, improve awareness/understanding on COVID-19 and to facilitate the distribution of Hygiene Kits and Food Packages.
Through these activities and by using a multi sectoral approach addressing protection, health and nutrition and WASH concerns, older people and persons with disabilities will be identified and their critical needs supported through appropriate interventions.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support to health system contact tracing as COVID-19 response Donetsk Oblast

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention will focus on COVID-19 affected districts of Donetsk Oblast and will evolve along with the evolution of the outbreak, with the overall aim of containing the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic and decrease of morbidity and mortality. It is based on PUI’s experience in implementing health programs in Donetsk oblast, working directly with primary healthcare facilities along the contact line. Affected districts will be primarily be supported through capacity building and on-the-ground support. PUI’s proposed action focuses on the following:
1) Affected districts to be supported through capacity building of healthcare professionals, and later on community-based organizations. This process will be conducted remotely, whenever possible, and with the support of a tracing platform. To enhance communication, selected locations will be provided with mobile phones.
2) In case of rapid increase in the number of cases, leading to a lack of local capacity to respond, on-the-ground support may be provided to districts on their contract tracing efforts. This response will be launched with the expressed need of health facilities. Field teams will be briefed on personal protection and have access to PPE.
3) Provision of PPE kits and an incentive for fuel and mobile connection for health facilities will be provided.
As a pilot project, continuous monitoring will ensure outcomes of the project quickly feed it and adapt the response.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency home-based assistance to the most vulnerable households with elderly people residing in Donetska and Luhanska GCAs in response to the COVID-19 outbreak

description.narrative: To respond to the COVID-19 outbreak, PAH will implement an emergency project focused on the provision of home-based assistance to the households with elderly people residing in nine isolated rural settlements along the “contact line” of Donetska and Luhanska oblasts. The home-based assistance will include provision of hygiene and food kits, personal protection equipment (PPE) kits for COVID-19 patients and remote psychosocial support to the households with elderly people during the period of three months. Moreover, in targeted settlements, PAH will distribute awareness-raising materials developed by WHO on COVID-19 to the local population to disseminate information on how to minimize the spread of the virus. In total 1200 most vulnerable households will receive hygiene kits and 1848 individuals (all household members) will be assisted with food kits. Additionally, 5% of targeted households will be provided with additional hygiene kits for people with special needs and 100 PPE kits will be distributed to the households with COVID-19 patients with mild symptoms. Elderly members of households will be also provided with psychosocial support via phone by PAH community workers. In total 10724 residents of nine rural isolated settlements will benefit from the provision of awareness-raising materials on COVID-19.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancement of home-delivered assistance in isolated settlements along the contact line due to COVID-19

description.narrative:
Our project is aimed at providing Enhancement of home-delivered assistance in isolated settlements along the contact line due to COVID-19. The project includes comprehensive assistance to elderly people living alone, the most vulnerable elderly people and people with disabilities in isolated settlements along the contact line in Government Controlled Areas of Donetska and Luhanska oblasts. Within the framework of the project, we will carry out the following activities: - 30 additional social workers from among local residents in isolated settlements along the “contact line” will provide home-based care to some 1000 elderly people living alone, the most vulnerable elderly people and people with disabilities, visiting each of them at least 1-2 times per week. The assistance will also include provision of food, hygiene kits and based on the need, social workers will also replenish the supply of medicines for older people from the nearest pharmacies, according to the prescription for the beneficiary's funds, ensuring the delivery of medicines to older people at home. - 4500 food sets will be delivered to the home of elderly people and people with disabilities living in isolated settlements along the contact line - 3000 hygiene kits will be provided to 3000 families of elderly people and persons with disabilities (about 4500 persons) in the isolated settlements along the contact line - 15000 residents of isolated communities will be informed on COVID-19 - 75 electric bicycles (40 of which at the expense of this project and 35 under UNHCR funding) will be purchased by Proliska for social workers, community leaders, postmen and local paramedics in order to increase their mobility in terms of providing the home-based care for the elderly and providing them with food, hygiene kits and medical services at home. The target group of the project are elderly people in need of home-based care, including provision of services, food and hygiene during quarantine.
NGO "Proliska" has been operating in Luhanska and Donetska oblasts since July 2014. Our organization has got many years of experience in implementing projects in the conflict zone: from 2016 to the present, we are the executive partners of UNHCR since 2019 we are implementing the project with UHF, in 2016-2018 we were the executive partners of UNICEF, since 2019 we are the partners of the Ministry of Temporary Occupied Territories and Internally Displaced People. Currently, the organization has more than 130 employees who are the members of the communities along the ‘contact line’. Thanks to this, we have a positive reputation in the communities and access to all the settlements with limited access where we carry out activities. Our employees are qualified specialists, having mainly 5 years of experience of work in the conflict zone.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Addressing multi-sectoral relief measures to elder people in 0-5 km area along the contact line isolated due to COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine, 2020

description.narrative: The Caritas Ukraine project using its network of 4 local offices currently operating along contact line, provides response on COVID-19 to 3232 elder people (64% females and 36% males) living in 1982 households in 13 settlements in 0-5 area along contact line in Donetska and Luhanska oblasts, GCA. Programming includes specific needs of 292 people with diabetes and 120 immobile people. Project provides home-delivered assistance with following measures: distribution of 8820 usual food kits (that secure nutrition of and individual during 3 months period) to 2940 individuals, distribution of 876 food kits with appropriate content for people with diabetes to 292 individuals, distribution of 1982 small family hygiene kits to beneficiaries households and 120 hygiene kits for people with specific needs. Project provides information campaign on COVID-19 and distribution of PPE kits to beneficiaries in case of suspected infection. Project intervention takes 3 months period and designed as fast emergency response in settlements of presence of Caritas current programs in coordination with other actors. Project preparation is based on participation of local authorities and activists (focal points) in the settlements of intervention. Project targets the most vulnerable people in rural settlements that have got sufficient transportation restrictions to nearby towns like Severodonetsk, Svitlodarsk, Avdiivka, Volnovakha and Mariupol where COVID-19 cases are observed. Quarantine measures cause incredibly low accessibility and affordability of essential goods in selected settlements and high risks of infection in case people have no choice but go to nearby towns for essential goods. Project to be fulfilled by operational capacity of existing experienced mobile teams trained, properly equipped and trained on safety and security protocols, Safeguarding Policy principles and Sphere 2018 standards.
